PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Panizza) agreed to:

That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to provide for an extension of the definition of isolated areas to include the seas situated in certain adjacent areas.
Motion (by Senator Panizza) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
This Bill seeks to amend an anomaly in the Income Tax Assessment Act in the implementation of the rebates allowed in disadvantaged remote areas as designated by Zone A and Zone B.

The rebate available through the Zone A and Zone B, as defined in the present legislation, ceases at Australia's shore line or the shore line of an off-shore island. This means that any man-made construction such as an oil rig or oil and gas platform in those seas off the shore of either Zone is not regarded as being part of that Zone.
The legislation was drafted before such expansion of engineering and technology to erect ocean installations.

By this Bill the problem areas will be covered by extending the land areas in Zone A and Zone B by an imaginary line from the shore point parallel to either the equator or lines of longitude out to Australia's territorial limit.

It is interesting to note that the government has just amended the Income Tax Act to include these very situations that I am addressing in the provisions for Fringe Benefit Tax. So this is an opportune time to address this point for the Zone A and Zone B, so that claims for rebate can be made by those living and working in those areas.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and table the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to move General Business notice of motion No. 791 standing in my name, relating to tariff cuts.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion No. 28, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Coulter) moving a motion relating to the order of business on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask honourable senators to bear in mind that this allows half an hour for debate on this matter, with five minutes per speaker. The Democrats are convinced that there should be no further reductions in tariffs whatsoever while this country suffers from its very high rate of unemployment—a rate of unemployment which is increasing; a rate of unemployment which, if one looks at figures in recent days, indicates that the numbers of long term unemployed, those people who are absolutely desperate, is increasing at a remarkably rapid rate.

PARA.TAB: If one were to accept for the moment the argument put by both the Government and the Opposition that tariff reduction will improve the economy in the longer term, then there may be some validity in tariff reduction, provided that there are other jobs available for those people who are displaced by the reduction in tariffs and the closure of the large number of businesses that are collapsing all around the country since this tariff reduction has been in place. But opportunities for alternative employment are not there. It is totally unconscionable that both the Government and the Opposition should continue to proceed with tariff reductions at this time.

There has been a lot of debate recently as to whether there are differences between the Government and the Opposition in relation to tariff reductions. The Government, particularly in the person of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), has been desperately attempting to show that there are differences between the Government and the Opposition in this area. But I note that most of the commentators who have looked very carefully at the statements made by both sides have observed that there is no difference at all in policy, that Mr Keating is merely attempting to create an impression that there is a difference. Dr Hewson is well aware of this.

SPEECH.PARA: I quote from a statement which appeared in the Australian on Friday:
Dr Hewson said on ABC radio last night he did not believe the Coalition's tariff proposal was handicapping it—
specifically in Wills—
because it was `in the context of a very substantial program of reform over the rest of the decade'.
I'd make two points. One is there really isn't all that much difference between our two policies—

that is, the policy of the Government and the policy of the Opposition. We want to put it fairly and squarely on the record that, at this time with a million people unemployed, with a growing number of unemployed, with a very high unemployment rate among the young, and with people who are becoming permanently unemployable as a consequence of the tariff reduction policies and the consequent closure of businesses, it is absolutely unconscionable to blindly pursue this economic rationalist reduction in tariffs which exacerbates the situation. It may be reasonable to do it at a time when there is high and growing employment, but not at this time. We call on both the Government and the Opposition to reverse their positon on tariff reductions. We call on the Government to halt tariff reductions until there is a substantial turnaround in employment opportunities.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will oppose the suspension of Standing Orders because the argument put by Senator Coulter is so patently and obviously invalid. It is terrifying to think that the Democrats can come here today and argue that Australia return to former policies, when it should be so obvious to all that the further internationalisation of our economy is in the best interests of creating jobs, rather than ending jobs.
—Stop the reductions now; that is what we are saying.

—We have a small economy and a small population. There are enormous markets and enormous opportunities out there for us. But we cannot have it both ways. Australia is debating in GATT at the present time and has been debating in the Uruguay Round since 1986 for a reduction in international barriers, not only in respect of agriculture, which is of particular importance to us, but also in other areas such as the service industry, intellectual property and investment-related opportunities. There is a need to give the Australian economy the chance to expand internationally and so enable growth and jobs to be created. We cannot have it both ways. Australia cannot go to GATT or other international bodies and argue that others should reduce barriers in order for us to have greater opportunity, whilst at the same time arguing that the barriers we have in this country should be retained.

PARA.TAB: Fortunately, the Australian Democrats seem to be the only political grouping in this country which still cannot see that argument and they are fairly irrelevant these days in any event. Australia needs to internationalise and seize the opportunities in those international markets. We cannot do that by maintaining barriers whilst at the same time arguing that others should reduce them to give us those opportunities.

When I mentioned agriculture, Senator Coulter pointed to my colleague Senator Boswell. Senator Boswell knows the opportunities that will arise for Australian rice farmers when the markets in Japan and Korea are opened. Under the GATT proposals and the Dunkel compromise, both markets would be open and this will give new opportunities for Australian agricultural producers. The Democrats cannot argue that they should be opened whilst at the same time arguing that Australian protection should be maintained.

The bipartisan trade committee of this Parliament which was sent to Europe last year found that there is still appalling ignorance within Europe, and within France in particular. There is a belief that the Democrat position reigns supreme, and that there is a general view amongst Australian Government policy-makers that tariffs should be maintained. Europe does not understand that there have already been reductions in industrial areas in Australia. But they said to us, `Unless you are prepared to bring those barriers down, you cannot expect to have the new opportunities that can be created in the international community'.

Australia should be concentrating on increasing domestic efficiency. If we can be domestically efficient in our production, then we can be competitive. That is what the whole coalition policy is all about. It is about getting the cost of business down and cutting the cost of government in particular. It is about getting the taxation burden off businesses. That is why we are advocating cutting $20 billion a year off business taxation. This will enable business to be efficient again, to expand and to employ Australians.

That is why our policy seeks to reform industrial relations. There is a need for both labour and employers to join together to negotiate employment agreements that can provide maximum opportunity and efficiency. That is why we advocate reform of infrastructure in this country. We need to be internationally competitive. We need to get rid of the cost burdens that are imposed on our producers by the waterfront and transport systems in Australia. If we concentrate on those areas, we will then have an opportunity to be internationally competitive again.

However, if we go back to the dark ages of Democrat policy and argue that the barriers should go up and if in some way we isolate ourselves from the international community and international competition, the result in this country will be an ever-lowering standard of living—which is the legacy we have inherited from 10 years of Labor—and a lack of opportunity for business to expand. We already have the tragedy of nearly one million unemployed. What do the Democrats want to do? Do they want to quarantine or lock in the one million unemployed? That is not the answer to Australia's economic future. We must open up, get out there, compete and provide jobs. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind honourable senators that we are debating whether Standing Orders should be suspended.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for that reminder, Mr President. The Government will not be supporting the suspension of Standing Orders in relation to this matter, principally because we regard it as a motion based on a fundamental misunderstanding of the way in which investment decisions are taken in this country and, therefore, the way jobs are created in response to those investment decisions. If the Government adopted this proposal and changed the law today, and if there were a view that changing those laws would create more jobs, not one job would be created this year. There are things called lead times and realities that keep coming up and hitting the Democrats between the eyes when they come up with wish list proposals such as this.

PARA.TAB: The progressive industries in Australia, the industries that the Democrats are seeking to protect in this instance, have been asking for some degree of understanding of the climate within which they will have to invest—the medium term climate in which their industry will need to operate. They do not want some sort of quick fix today saying, `We won't do anything until some future notice and then we might start again'. That would mean that when they invest today they would not know what the investment climate is going to be in six, 12 or 18 months time. It is exactly the wrong position to take. It would stop anybody investing because there would be that worst of all situations—uncertainty. It is a guarantee of failure, whereas, the position that the Government set down on 12 March last year—contrary to some of the breathless responses to more recent comments—remains in place and no-one is proposing to change what we set down on 12 March last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your Prime Minister seems to be changing it.
—He has not said that at all.
—I said that he seems to be changing.

—He only seems to be because some people do not understand what was said on 12 March, which was said clearly, which Senator Button reiterated yesterday, which continues to be the policy of the Government and which gives certainty to people who wish to invest. They know the climate. I disagree strongly with the Opposition's zero proposal, but at least if the Opposition were elected and put that proposal in place, people would have some understanding of the climate within which they were investing. Many of them would chose not to invest because they would not like the climate, but that is a different issue. I do not agree with that policy; that is very clear.

PARA.TAB: The case for tariffs, going back to the 1950s, was for some sort of protection of infant industries. I remember that thesis. There might have been some justification for that in the 1950s. I have a bit of doubt about that even, but let us assume there was. If a protection of infant industries argument applied in the 1950s, the infant industries we have in Australia today do not want that protection, and they want the overlay of excessive protection that arose from the 1950s taken away from the industries which are their suppliers.

It is not the case that we have some sort of need to protect the newly emerging sunrise industries. They do not want that protection. They are delighted that there is a program to get rid of that massive superstructure of McEwenism, and also that we can now get down to an agreed known schedule of reductions so that we still have a motor vehicle industry and a TCF industry—and we do. Investment is taking place on the basis of the known program set down by the Government. We have an existing and understood program under which, for example, substantial investment in the motor vehicle industry is taking place at this time. In the last few weeks we have seen the Prime Minister involved in the launching of the major initiatives for both Toyota and General Motors, investments that have taken place—

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he go to the closing down of Nissan?

—Senator Panizza knows that Nissan failed to make a profit 17 years in a row under the massive protection policies of the past. Nissan has not been driven out of business by lack of protection, it has been driven out of business by lack of profits. Too many people were trying to participate in the market. What we want is an existing and understood program to get the tariff levels down to a manageable level so that we can continue to have industries in which employment can be created, but so that the new industries can grow in a climate of international competitiveness and efficiency. (Time expired)

—The Australian Democrats have called for the suspension of Standing Orders to allow a debate in which we would call for a halt at this point to the tariff cuts program of the Government. We want to bring to close attention the disaster of the tariff cuts regime implemented at this stage by the Government, and supported by the Opposition whose own scorched earth policy is only a matter of degree by way of difference from that of the Government.

PARA.TAB: In the contributions thus far on the question of whether this debate should take place on this motion for suspension of Standing Orders, the Democrats' position has been, as usual, grossly misrepresented. It is not the Democrats' intention that we should go backwards on the issue of tariff policy in this country; it is not our intention that we should re-erect around our industries and across the board the brick wall that was erected in the days of `Black Jack' McEwen. Although let it be said that, at its time, much of what happened in the post-Second World War era was appropriate. We acknowledge that what is needed is a targeted policy and one which, at the moment, needs to be changed because of the drastic and tragic levels of unemployment in this country.

I will remind the Senate of that situation. We have only to look at the very recent past to see the tragic nature of the problem, a problem which really cannot be overstated. Between January 1990 and January 1992, unemployment almost doubled from 550,400 to 960,000—that is almost one million people. Then, of course, there are the dependants in the families of those people who suffer under the burden of unemployment. We are facing the fact that unemployment will rise above that figure and, indeed, is above that figure in hidden unemployment—a point which the Opposition continues to pursue—because many people such as young people, women and even family breadwinners, have given up looking for jobs.

The number of people who have been out of work for one year or more almost trebled in that same two-year period from 115,900 to 274,200. Unemployment is a massive problem. These days we have changed our definitions. Long term unemployment now means having been unemployed for more than a year, whereas previously it meant having been unemployed for only six months. We are reclassifying the tragedy of unemployment in this country.

Let me make it clear what the Australian Democrats are proposing: we are proposing that the tariff cuts program of the Government, which has got out of hand and which is ignoring the social cost that it is placing on the community, stops now. We see the by-election in Wills as being a very important demonstration of the damage that has been created. In that electorate the TCF industries are prominent, or at least have been prominent.

Senator McMullan, in his contribution, talked about what industry is saying it wants—it wants to be able to set goals, it wants to be able to plan ahead. In the TCF industries that is exactly what has happened and yet factories continue to close down. Last year 18 factories closed down in the electorate of Wills, 600 jobs were lost and a further 2,000 jobs are at risk. The TCF Council has made its views very clear about what it wants and, indeed, has exhorted people in the electorate of Wills to vote for the Australian Democrats to really send a message to this place about tariff policy.

The Democrats are saying that a meeting of TCF employees and unions should be called to identify the specific products and industry sectors which need increased tariff protection in the context of the Government's program; that these should be implemented; that emergency procedures should be initiated to reduce the damage caused by dumping of cheap imports; and that these measures should be extended to other industries.

We are listening, too, to what industry is saying; we are seeing what is happening to the people. The hoax that Prime Minister Keating has tried to perpetrate on the people of Wills—that there is an essential difference between the Government and the Opposition—is not working. We are already seeing that in the polls. It is quite clear that the targeted, socially conscious position that the Australian Democrats are taking on tariffs is not going back into the past, it is future orientated and it is people orientated. The people of Wills are demonstrating that and they will vote for the Democrat and Independent wedge on 11 April.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I would also remind honourable senators, as the President did, that we are supposed to be debating whether Standing Orders should be suspended.

—I, too, am opposed to the suspension of Standing Orders. I listened very closely to Senator Powell's comments to hear whether there was any substance to them. Senator Powell really gave the game away in the last part of her remarks. This is really just a plain, fact-of-the-matter, Wills by-election stunt. Basically, if what Senator Powell proposes in this motion could assist in the tragedy of unemployment, most members in this Parliament would strongly support it. However, the reality is that it will not help unemployment.

PARA.TAB: When protection in the textiles, clothing and footwear industries was at its highest level in 1990, 17,000 jobs were lost in those industries. We have to ask ourselves whether the Australian Democrats are fair dinkum in their concern about unemployment. I have been a member of this chamber for almost two years, and I have listened in vain for any evidence from the Australian Democrats that they are prepared in any way to assist industry to create jobs.

What major mining project have the Australian Democrats supported which would create jobs throughout this community? Has Senator Kernot come into this chamber and strongly supported the major Tully-Millstream development, which would not only create jobs in the construction of that mighty project but would also provide the power and energy for future developments in Queensland? We heard not a word. Did Senator Coulter support the Coronation Hill project, which apparently the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, appears to support at times but then backflips? Did Senator Powell support that major development? There was not a word. Did Senator Bell come into this chamber and support the Wesley Vale pulp mill development in Tasmania? No. Of course the Democrats do not support it. They have vigorously opposed it.

I wonder what representatives of industry will think when members of the Opposition explain to them that what the Australian Democrats want to do is to put a vast range of new taxes on industry. I wonder what industry will think of the additional taxes on power that the Australian Democrats wish to propose. I wonder what industries feel about the additional transport taxes that Senator Coulter proposes. I wonder what they think about the additional fuel taxes that the Democrats propose. I wonder what all those taxes will do for Australian industry.

In terms of employment, I wonder what the Australian people, particularly those in small business, will think about Senator Coulter's proposal and the incentives it will create for wealth taxes, inheritance taxes and capital gains taxes. I wonder what all those small business people in Wills will think about that when they have struggled to maintain and to build up their shops and their small factories and they know that the Australian Democrats are proposing a vast range of taxes which will not only inhibit their current operations but will certainly ensure that any incentive to build up a business no longer exists.

A recent report from the Business Council of Australia pointed out that one of the major problems in Australian manufacturing industry, about which you, Mr Deputy President, have evinced concern, is the very high level of taxes that the manufacturing industry must bear compared with that borne by its major competitors overseas. The recent Business Council Bulletin spelt that out very clearly indeed.When we listen to Senator Coulter, we wonder whether he has any proposal on the table to address this particular problem. The answer is that he does not want to remove taxes from the manufacturing industry. His policies would impose further taxes.

The coalition has put down a major package of assistance, the Fightback package, which attempts to at last tilt the field in favour of the manufacturing industry in this country; to rid the manufacturing industry of the vast burden of taxes. Will Senator Powell support us in our proposal to remove the payroll tax? Will Senator Powell support us in our proposal to remove the wholesale sales tax? Will Senator Powell support us in our proposal to cut the cost of transport taxes in this country? The answer is that she will not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion to suspend Standing Orders will fail, as has been made quite clear. Perhaps it is proper to point out why. Senator Coulter asked that his motion on the paper, motion No. 791, be taken as formal. When a motion is taken as formal, as you know better than I, Mr Deputy President, it shall be put and determined without amendment or debate. So what has been proposed here today by the Australian Democrats is that a motion relating to tariff cuts and unemployment, about which clearly there are considerable differences in the various parts of the chamber, be put without debate.

PARA.TAB: It has been made quite clear here this morning that there are different solutions to the country's many problems. It would be wrong to put a motion of this sort through this House without there being considerable debate. Unfortunately, the request by Senator Coulter has symbolised what often happens in the debates in this chamber. People take up positions and refuse to debate the facts that they are faced with.

The Australian economy, like economies elsewhere around the world at the moment, is in much need of rejuvenation. The way to rejuvenate the economy, to make things better than they are now, is to look at the actual problems that face the people of this country and to give answers to those problems in terms of reality, in terms of what is needed. That answer is not going to be given in terms of a sweeping philosophy or a sweeping principle, such as `Let's abolish tariff cuts from now on; let's stop the tariff cuts'.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage, just a halt.

—To be fair to Senator Coulter, he says that he is not saying `Let's abolish tariff cuts'. He is saying, `Let's stop them here and now'. That may be an appropriate course to take in terms of the TCF industries. It may be an appropriate course to take in terms of other industries as well, but it would be wrong for us as a parliament to pass a motion which simply says, `Let's stop all tariff cuts right across every industry, right across the board'. It is too simplistic a solution to a very complex problem.

PARA.TAB: That tendency is not confined to Senator Coulter or to the Democrats. There is a tendency, say in terms of putting forward the policies of the Fightback package, to lack flexibility. Here is a scheme that has been put forward by the Opposition which has a considerable amount of material that has to be considered. But there seems an inability on the part of the Opposition to change in any way the ideology which it has adopted in the Fightback package.

SPEECH.PARA: DEFENCE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992
The Defence Legislation Amendment Bill makes various amendments to:
revise provisions concerning conscription and conscientious objection;
enable the appointment of the Assistant Chief of the Defence Force (Personnel) to the Defence Housing Authority;
tidy up legislation providing for Defence retirement benefits and home loans assistance schemes; and
repeal obsolete retirement benefits provisions.

In this speech I will concentrate on the revision of the conscription and conscientious objection provisions. The other matters are straightforward and are sufficiently covered by the explanatory memorandum.

The only legislation currently in force which provides for conscription and conscientious objection is contained in Part IV of the Defence Act, which limits compulsory military service to a time of war. In this context, it is important to note that "time of war" has a defined and limited meaning: a period of actual or apprehended enemy invasion of, or attack on, Australia. I would like to assure the Senate that the current amendments do not alter this fundamental threshold. The Government's view continues to be that conscription could be justified where Australia is directly threatened but not otherwise.

The amendments now proposed stem from the Government's decision, announced in the Senate by Senator Evans on 5 December 1986, to accept recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. The essential changes would add recognition of conscientious objection to particular conflicts, as distinct from war in general, and require prior parliamentary approval of conscription.

I doubt that anyone would argue these days against the requirement for prior parliamentary approval of conscription. The desirability of providing for conscientious objection to particular conflicts might not be quite so self evident. However, the Government was persuaded by the view of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs that, in some cases, an individual's sense of personal integrity could be violated by compulsion to participate in a particular military conflict but not in other conflicts.
An important element of the new provisions is definition of a person's conscientious belief as one that:
involves a fundamental conviction of what is morally right and morally wrong, whether or not based on religious considerations;
is so compelling in character for that person that he or she is duty bound to espouse it; and
is likely to be of a long standing nature.

This definition would give clear guidance to tribunals considering claims of conscientious belief but is sufficiently broad to ensure coverage of any genuine case. Although Australian legislation has recognised conscientious objection to compulsory military service for more than 80 years, the nature of the conscientious belief required has been determined largely by judicial decisions on claims. In this most significant area, the Government believes that the Parliament by legislation should set out the key characteristics of conscientious belief to ensure that there is clear and consistent guidance for future decisions.

Another important innovation is provision for establishment of special conscientious objection tribunals. (Of course, such tribunals would only be established in the most unlikely event of conscription to meet a threat to Australia.)

The old model, of traditional adversarial proceedings before a magistrate, has been abandoned as inappropriate. New tribunals would be established for the specific purpose of determining claims of conscientious beliefs. They would be composed of a presiding member, who had at least 7 years experience as a legal practitioner, and 2 other members, who were capable of ascertaining facts other than by adversarial procedures.

The legislation specifically requires conscientious objection tribunals to adopt quick, fair, just and economical procedures. They are also required to act according to substantial justice and the merits of the case, and are not bound by technicalities, legal forms or rules of evidence. Although the tribunals are clearly expected to operate as informally as possible, they are given sufficient formal powers (such as the capacity to summon witnesses) to exercise their functions.

Conscientious objection tribunals would normally take oral evidence in public but would have a discretion to take evidence in private or to take written evidence. A person claiming exemption from service because of a conscientious belief would bear the onus of proof, on the balance of probabilities.

The right of appeal from conscientious objection tribunals would be to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Further appeal to the Federal Court would be allowed on a question of law or, with the leave of the Court, on any other ground.

In the review of the current legislation, the opportunity has been taken to remove discriminatory provisions, e.g. where obligations depend on whether a person is a "male person", a "British subject" or an "Aboriginal native". These amendments are quite clearly well overdue.

I am particularly pleased that this Bill proposes the repeal of the National Service Act 1951. It is, of course, true that this Act has for all practical purposes been defunct since 1972. The Whitlam Government disbanded the national service scheme in December 1972 and the National Service Termination Act 1973 removed any legal obligation to register for or render national service.

The National Service Act was not repealed at that time because some national servicemen continued voluntarily in the Army. The Act has remained on the statute books, even though defunct. Repeal of the Act will remove this last vestige of an unhappy and divisive episode in our history. Despite the repeal, any entitlements that may have accrued to individuals through rendering national service have been explicitly preserved, where necessary.

This outline has necessarily been condensed. However, I trust that it has indicated the substantial improvements that would be in place if ever there was a requirement to introduce conscription and to hear claims for exemption based on conscientious belief. The Government's aim has been to preserve the capacity to introduce conscription for the protection of Australia, but to ensure that those claiming exemption would receive a rapid and fair hearing.
I commend the Bill to the Senate. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
CORPORATION LEGISLATION (EVIDENCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

The purpose of this Bill is to remove certain immunities available to witnesses under the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) Law and the Corporations Law. The need for the legislation arises from difficulties encountered by the Australian Securities Commission in investigating complex corporate frauds, to which I shall refer shortly.
At the outset, however, it is necessary to understand the background against which the issues addressed in this Bill arise.

It has been an established rule of the common law, since the 17th century, that a person can not be compelled to incriminate himself, and may refuse to answer any question, or produce any document or thing, which may put him at risk of conviction. This rule arose out of the principle, fundamental to our system of justice, that the Crown must prove the guilt of accused persons, rather than allow the executive to require suspects to convict themselves out of their own mouths.

In various circumstances, however, legislatures have recognised that the intended purpose of a statute may only be achieved by either limiting or abrogating this privilege against self-incrimination. The superseded co-operative scheme companies legislation, which preceded the current national scheme legislation, was such a case. Under that scheme the National Companies and Securities Commission could conduct examinations in which the common law privilege against self-incrimination was excluded by legislation. In return, the legislation provided an immunity, known as the "use immunity", which prevented answers which tended to be self-incriminatory from later being used in evidence against a person in criminal proceedings or proceedings for the imposition of a penalty.

In 1983, the then Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia, in the decision Sorby v The Commonwealth (1983) 152 CLR 281, criticised a narrow application of such use immunities, stating that evidence obtained through, or derived from, the evidence protected by the use immunity, should also be inadmissible in proceedings against the person—the so-called "derivative use immunity".

This suggestion was taken up by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, when in its 1984 Report on the National Crime Authority Bill 1983 it advocated that where the privilege against self-incrimination was abolished by Parliament, the prosecution should be unable to use in evidence either the actual incriminating words and documents produced under compulsion, or any evidence discovered as a result of those words and documents. This "use/derivative use immunity" is now applied by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.
In reporting on the Australian Securities Commission Bill, however, the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation stated, at paragraph 4.60, its belief that:

subclause 68(3) [drafted in compliance with the Scrutiny of Bills Committee's policy of "use/derivative use immunity"] will not unnecessarily or unacceptably act to abrogate the privilege against self-incrimination if it were amended to apply only to statements made by a person and not to any information, document or any other thing obtained as a direct or indirect consequence of the person making the statement.

Though suggesting that removal of the derivative use immunity would be appropriate, the Committee did not include a recommendation to that effect in its Report. Subsection 68(3) of the ASC Law therefore provides a use/derivative use immunity in respect of information obtained by the ASC in investigations.

The Australian Securities Commission and the Director of Public Prosecutions, the agencies responsible respectively for investigating and prosecuting corporate fraud, have been experiencing serious problems in bringing effective prosecutions as the "use immunity" prevents the admission of evidence of the fact that a particular person produced a particular document, and the "derivative use immunity" protects evidence gained as a result of answers to questions.

The problems being experienced may be understood from a hypothetical example—to protect shareholders and creditors of a corporation under investigation, the ASC may consider that its assets should be frozen and its dealings restrained. To do this, evidence may need to be obtained under compulsion from a key person. However, as any incriminating information gained, together with any evidence derived from that information, would attract immunity, that person could not subsequently be prosecuted. To avoid this, the ASC may try to obtain the evidence without questioning major suspects. While it does so, assets may be concealed or dissipated, disadvantaging creditors and shareholders. Thus, pursuit of remedies for the protection of shareholders and creditors may prevent successful criminal prosecutions, while major suspects, whose evidence could uncover other serious offences calling for wider inquiries, tend to be questioned narrowly, if at all, because the derivative use immunity provisions would allow them to escape conviction and punishment.

It is also possible for persons to exploit, quite consciously, the immunity provisions, by claiming that answers may tend to be self-incriminating, then making a full confession, thereby ensuring that no evidence will be admissible against them in criminal proceedings.

Another problem arising from the application of the provisions is that complex cases involve the admission into evidence of hundreds, even thousands, of documents, all or many of which may be challenged by the defence on the grounds of derivative use immunity. This has the potential to make cases extremely lengthy and costly.

Finally, because the fact that a person has produced a document is not admissible against the person, the link between the person's original possession of the document and its introduction into evidence against the person is broken. This may mean that the person escapes conviction because an essential link in the chain of evidence is missing.

In developing the new corporations and securities legislation the aim was to balance the conflicting interests of efficient business, shareholders and creditors, civil liberties and effective law enforcement, so as to achieve a workable result.

The law as it stands at present fails to take adequate account of the difficulties faced by the ASC and the DPP, the bodies responsible for effectively investigating and prosecuting corporate crime. The practical position is that the ASC can not use its powers to investigate certain suspected criminal activity. The problems of proof created by the derivative use immunity and the immunity for the fact of a person signing a record or producing a document are affecting its role in corporate law enforcement.

The issue was recently re-examined by the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, which in its report tabled on 15 November 1991, recommended the removal of the derivative use immunity from the national scheme, together with the use immunity with regard to the fact that a person has produced a document. It also recommended that corporations be expressly excluded from claiming the privilege against self-incrimination. These recommendations followed the recognition that the availability of full use/derivative use immunity is threatening to defeat the purpose of significant portions of the corporations legislation.

This Bill adopts those recommendations by removing the derivative use immunity from subsection 68(3) of the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989, and from subsection 597(12) of the Corporations Law contained in section 82 of the Corporations Act 1989. It removes the immunity in respect of the fact that a person had produced a document from subsection 68(3) of the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989, and confines the availability of the remaining use immunity to natural persons.

Under proposed section 1316A of the Corporations Law, a body corporate will not be entitled to claim the privilege against self-incrimination, nor claim that it may make itself liable to a penalty, in any Corporations Law criminal proceedings. Nor may it claim privilege or acquire any immunity under proposed subsections 68(3) or 597(12) and (12A).

The removal of the right to claim the privilege against self-incrimination from bodies corporate in the legislation is to overcome the uncertainty resulting from the decision of the High Court of Australia in Pyneboard Pty Ltd v Trade Practices Commission (1983) 152 CLR 328 where it was assumed, but not decided, that the common law privilege against selfincrimination applied to corporations. In that case Murphy J (at p. 346) expressed the view that:

the privilege is personal, so that one required to produce documents cannot resist production on the ground that this would tend to incriminate another. The history and reasons for the privilege do not justify its extension to artificial persons such as corporations or political entities. . .
The Government endorses this view, and that of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, which said at paragraph 4.5 of it's report, that:

"Companies are artificial legal entities occupying a privileged position in that all companies are protected by limited liability and public companies may seek investment from the public. . . . This privileged position carries with it obligations of accountability which may require the restriction of the rights of those participating in the corporate sector, including the right to remain silent.

The Bill does not, however, adopt a further recommendation of the Committee, that there be a five year sunset clause on these amendments. The reason for not following that recommendation is that serious problems could arise in the prosecution of matters which may have been under investigation for some time. Investigators in complex cases would be hampered by the uncertainty of not knowing which rule of evidence would apply at the time of trial, and prosecutions not completed when the immunities revive would be jeopardised by the inadmissibility of crucial evidence. This would involve not only considerable expense in wasted resources over a long period of time, but would also significantly detract from the Government's public commitment to more effective law enforcement in the corporate area.

A preferable alternative is to ensure that the operation of the amendments is reviewed within a specified period, and Cabinet has decided that an appropriate period is five years. Thus, in accordance with that decision the operation of these amendments will be reviewed after five years of operation. However, the Government has given its commitment that their operation will be monitored and an interim review will take place after twelve months.

The Government is committed to the objective of ensuring that the law can not be used to protect from prosecution those individuals who direct corporate activity and who have breached the law. I believe that the solution represented by the Bill appropriately balances the competing interests of civil liberties, inherited from centuries of the common law and fundamental to our system of criminal justice, with the responsibility of the Government to ensure that the laws of the Parliament are properly enforceable.

Effective corporate regulation in Australia requires legislation with teeth, in the form of criminal provisions which can be enforced. The Australian community expects corporate malfeasors to be exposed to the full ambit of the criminal justice system, not shielded from it by legislation, and that is the intention of the amendments contained in this Bill.
The proposals put forward in this Bill do not have an impact on Government expenditure.
I present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill, and commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991POULTRY INDUSTRY ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT BILL 1991

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2) and the Poultry Industry Assistance Amendment Bill, not so much to talk on the actual business of the Bills but to use them as a vehicle for discussion on the poultry industry.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the Poultry Industry Assistance Amendment Bill is to clean up old legislation under which debts from a previous arrangement have been unpaid. The hen levy as it was is no longer operative. There are still outstanding debts dating back prior to 1990 when the trust fund was wound up.

I refer to the importation of poultry meat, the question of quarantine and so on. Prior to 1990, the Australian Poultry Industries Association and the Australian Chicken Meat Federation had been involved in discussions with AQIS and its predecessors concerning the importation of poultry products into Australia. There had been discussions concerning importations from the United States and New Zealand, and, in every case, it was the quarantine aspects that dominated.

There is the question of newcastle disease, avian influenza and various other lesser known diseases, which are very real as far as the poultry industry is concerned and very important in retaining Australia's disease-free status in this area compared with the other countries.

On 16 March 1990, AQIS advised that it had been approached by the governments of the United States, New Zealand, Thailand and Denmark to allow the importation of either cooked or frozen poultry products. AQIS went on to announce that it was conducting a full quarantine risk assessment.

Australia is well-known throughout the world for its very generous quarantine assessments. The industry started to become nervous as to what might happen in this case. In due course, in April 1991, the risk assessment discussion paper was distributed with a response requested by 14 July. The fact that it was heavily dealt with by the industry meant that the date had to be extended somewhat.

The industry itself produced its own study, known as the Larkin report, and discussions have proceeded since then. The industry contacted Minister Crean and Minister Griffiths, various State Ministers of agriculture and health, as well as AQIS, to emphasise the effect of significant changes to quarantine and what such changes might do to the Australian industry.
In due course, on 3 December 1991, AQIS advised that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . consideration of the quarantine and public health issues associated with the importation of chicken products is still in progress. The work to date has concentrated on cooked product and we are still considering comments from interested parties on our discussion paper.

So the issue still rambles on. The concern for public health issues and the concern for industry quarantine issues are not quite the same, although they certainly overlap. It is necessary that they should be considered individually.The letter from AQIS went on to say:
We have not sought to develop a position on fresh frozen chicken meat at this stage in view of the complexity of the issues and the inadequacy of information from interested countries.
But as I say, we still ramble on, inexorably heading in that direction.

PARA.TAB: Australia is free of the various strains of newcastle disease. The last outbreak that we had of the virulent strain was in the early 1930s. Australia is also one of the few countries that does not allow the vaccination of any poultry against newcastle disease.

A recent AQIS discussion paper entitled A qualitative assessment of current exotic disease risks for Australia rates newcastle disease, along with avian influenza and bluetongue, in the highest priority group of diseases for exotic animal disease risk. One of the four ways it suggests that exotic newcastle disease could enter Australia is in foodstuffs containing infected poultry carcass material.

I really do not see that there is any necessity for Australia at this stage even to consider the importation of poultry carcass material. But we still persist. The report went on to say that frozen poultry carcasses were an important mode of the spread of the virulent newcastle disease from one country to another in the 1940s and 1950s. The 1990 AQIS paper suggests that, once the virus had entered the country, there is no reason why virulent newcastle disease would not become established in Australia and spread very rapidly.

The attitude that goes with so much of this is that we have to accept what is an acceptable level of risk. With diseases such as newcastle disease, foot and mouth disease and the like, the acceptable level of risk is zero—not zero plus one or 0.001, but zero. There is no reason in the world for Australia at this stage to run the risk of absolutely decimating what has now become a very well controlled and very well run business.

Should there be an outbreak of newcastle disease, the costs would be absolutely enormous and the destruction in the industry would be very high. The loss of standing as far as the Australian industry is concerned would be most damaging. The effect on wildlife is also something that has not really been checked and would be impossible to determine. If the disease could not be quickly eradicated, massive costs associated with mortality and loss of production due to the clinical disease, with purchasing and applying of vaccines and loss of trade, would be incurred on an ongoing basis.

Insufficient knowledge of the effects upon, and the spread of disease in, native bird species means that the effect on the bird population would, as I say, be inestimable. The Chicken Meat Research and Development Council and the Egg Industry Research and Development Council and their predecessors have spent $1.6m on newcastle disease-related research.

We have always had in mind that it is possible that, for some unknown reason, the disease could come to Australia. We certainly do not want to bring it in by some known means. We do not want to open up the industry to such an extent that it could suffer as a result of this.

For all these reasons, the Australian poultry industry totally opposes the importation of poultry products from countries known to have newcastle disease. It also totally opposes the importation from any country that routinely vaccinates poultry against newcastle disease. It is well recognised that vaccinated, apparently healthy birds may still harbour or shed the virulent strain.

Four countries have made application to export poultry products to Australia: Thailand, the United States, Denmark and New Zealand. The status of newcastle disease in Thailand and the USA should automatically eliminate those countries as possible exporters of poultry products to Australia. The exact situation in Denmark is still unclear, but as from 1992 Denmark will be fully integrated into the European Community which will act as a single trading unit, and we must, therefore, assess the disease status of the EC as a whole when considering Denmark.

Then we can consider avian influenza, which is another exotic disease of great concern to the poultry industry and is ranked alongside newcastle disease as one of the top three exotic animal disease risks for Australia.

I do not understand why it is that we are still spending a lot of time and a lot of money, and doing a lot more investigations to see how we can go about opening the doors to imports. I do not believe in using quarantine as an embargo, as a non-tariff barrier, but I certainly believe that this Government and this Parliament owes its first allegiance to its own industry. Why do we not just say, `The risk is too great. We are not prepared to run those sorts of risks and, accordingly, we do not see it as appropriate that we should change our policy at all on the importation of either cooked or raw and frozen poultry products'.

The industry itself now comprises 1,400 or 1,500 major establishments evenly divided between egg and meat production. It is an industry which now employs 45,000 to 50,000 people. The assets of the industry are worth about $1,400m, and that is on the basis of there being between 55 million and 60 million birds. The industry produces 400,000 tonnes of poultry meat and over 180 million dozen eggs a year. It is a very important industry in many rural and outer suburban areas.

The poultry industry has done a great job in its own promotion and presentation into the households of Australia. Consumption has risen from 4.4 kilograms per person per year in 1950 to 25.2 kilograms per person in 1990. This is, of course, white meat, which healthy people would tell us is better than steak—I have my personal reservations on that. Consumption of chicken meat is now second only to beef in Australia.

The industry does not intend to try to require the Government to object to imports on any grounds other than that of the risk to the industry itself. It is not worth bringing in products that will produce risks to the consumer and it certainly is not worth bringing into Australia anything that will run the risk of decimating or seriously damaging an industry which, over the last 20 or 30 years, has made such an effort to get its house in order—to rationalise; to become modern, effective and efficient—and which has spent considerable amounts of money on research and on producing the best birds possible for the purpose for which they are required. Accordingly, I will certainly support any move that will result in curtailing the extension of the import of poultry products.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak on the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), I wish to begin by making some comments concerning the amendments to the Meat Inspection Act. While these amendments streamline certain procedures, one must take the opportunity of emphasising the point that our current meat inspection arrangements are badly in need of overhaul. It is absolutely imperative, given that there is a 100 per cent recovery of costs in terms of the meat industry, that many of the inefficiencies in the meat inspection service be addressed. In addition, a significant number of meat inspectors are still in the employ of the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service, AQIS, and the industry is picking up the costs of those surplus meat inspectors.

PARA.TAB: The time has come for a major overhaul of the whole meat inspection or quarantine inspection services. While the industry has the 100 per cent recovery cost in terms of those inspectors and the service that is provided, it is entitled to a much greater say in terms of future directions. The time has come for the modernisation of the inspection service to get the inspectors themselves—and I am not arguing about the necessity of inspection for the export or domestic consumption of our meat products—tied to the various meatworks and become an integral part of the abattoirs operation. It is only by progressing down that path that we will maximise the productivity of meat inspectors and lower the costs involved. Currently the costs per man in the industry are as much as $93,000 per year, which is a very high cost for a service that is over-manned.

I also wish to take this opportunity whilst debating the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill—particularly in view of the current debate concerning tariffs—to try to put a balanced view on the position as it impacts on the industry. I wish to do this against the background of a number of aspects and state why it is important that we continue to have a reduction in tariffs across the board in rural and other industries. Together with those reductions in tariffs, it is imperative that the cost imposts on agricultural industries—the various primary industries—whether it be the sugar, beef, wool, wheat or the poultry industry that Senator Archer referred to—be reduced.

When talking about tariffs, it must be noted that the cost in Australia of the current tariff regime is about $8,000 per farm per year. This enormous tax has to be paid up front in terms of the protection provided to a number of industries in Australia. It was with much dismay last week that I read and heard of the backflip by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on his previous position on tariffs. Some three or four years ago—or maybe a little longer when I was on the executive of the National Farmers Federation—I heard the Prime Minister, when he was Treasurer, actually say that his policy position, in terms of having an efficient economy in Australia and taking us towards becoming internationally competitive, was that in time, and in the not too far distant future, we must phase out tariffs totally in Australia.

The Prime Minister also mentioned at that time the need to get the input costs to industry down. During that time, which would have been about 1984-85, he was advocating the introduction of a consumption tax. That is another one of his big backflips. If we look at what has occurred in recent days in terms of further amendments to the wholesale sales tax and a report that was presented to Senator Button yesterday, we realise that there are at least some advisers within the Government who recognise the importance of moving our tax base, lowering income tax rates and introducing a consumption tax. I wanted to put that on the public record because I was there when Mr Keating, as Treasurer, made that statement. It was more than a statement; it was a commitment. But that commitment has gone down the drain.

Let us look at tariffs in a little more detail and the impact of that $8,000 and compare the difference between the situation in the Australian farm sector and the situation in the US and the EC where there are very high levels of protection for the farm sector. In the EC the attrition rate—those being phased out of agriculture in the EC, despite its high levels of protection—has been running at about 16 per cent per year for a number of years. In the United States of America—the so-called bastion of free enterprise—which provides very high levels of protection for the farm sector through the farm Bill, through EEP and through other programs, the attrition rate is about 14 per cent.

Australia, where protection for the farm sector is much lower, has an attrition rate of about 6 per cent. In our larger industries—in saying our larger industries, I am not decrying the smaller industries—such as wheat, wool and beef, which have negligible levels of protection or assistance, losses are even less than that.

Tariffs, in terms of the farming industry, and also in terms of the individual in the street, are in effect a consumer tax. I have already highlighted the fact that there is a cost of some $8,000 per farm. The current tariff protection for the car industry costs consumers about $4,000 per car. If we look a little further down the track we find that, across the board, tariffs costs the average household about $16 a week. When people debate tariff policy, they must realise that protection for one person or for one industry is just a transfer across the board to another industry or individual of a consumer tax.

What is required in terms of our position on agriculture today? We have to be realistic about the situation in Europe and the United States vis-a-vis the GATT round and a number of other activities. In terms of the world tariff debate, very shortly—I think on 1 May—Japan will reduce its tariffs on beef by some 10 per cent, which will significantly benefit the Australian industry. It will allow some additional increase into the Japanese market but, more importantly, it will allow, over time, Australian producers to receive a higher price for their product, which will be flow across the board. It is totally irresponsible, after having won that debate with the Japanese and moving into other areas, for those in the Australian community to start talking up tariffs and presenting them as a panacea to many of our problems.

As I said before, it is a transfer from one consumer to the other or from one industry to the other. While we might protect a few jobs in one particular industry, this will be done at the cost—I emphasise this point—of jobs in another industry. An analysis of the whole tariff situation shows that tariffs have produced very few jobs in Australia; in fact, they have not protected the jobs of those people who work in protected industries. I refer to the much quoted textiles, clothing and footwear industry. In 1990, when levels of protection were very high, the industry shed some 17,000 jobs. The current debate is being fuelled by the Prime Minister's back flip on tariffs as a result of the Wills by-election, and the attempt by the Democrats today to debate in this place the issue. Somebody else in another electorate will have to pay for any increased tariffs in Wills. Any gain in jobs in Wills will, on a pro rata basis, be made at the expense of jobs in some other electorate.

To remain competitive in agriculture—and this applies across the board—we need to get our costs and our input taxes down. As outlined in the Fightback program, the wholesale sales tax impact needs to be taken off the backs of those people who are producing. Not only the direct cost of the wholesale sales tax but also the indirect costs of this tax flow through the system. Another tax that we intend to remove is payroll tax. We will take away the liability from the States in terms of raising money through payroll tax. Incidentally, every Premier in this country has called for the replacement of payroll tax because it is a tax on employment.

The flow-on impact of these taxes on the road transport industry is in the order of $53,000 per rig per year. That cost has to be picked up down the track and, in the final analysis, it is passed on to the producer. The effect of these taxes flows through to the various service industries which repair and supply second-hand or new machinery. Once again, this cost is picked up finally by the consumer.

Farmers across Australia have to pick up on average $8,000 per year in flow-on consumer taxes as a result of tariffs. This is in addition to the flow-on costs of wholesale sales tax, payroll tax, fuel excise and all the other indirect taxes that sit in the system. The Opposition proposes in the Fightback package that these taxes should be taken out of the system. Industry costs—whether they be in agriculture, manufacturing or mining—have to be lowered so that the industries can have a cost structure that will enable them to be world competitive. It is worth noting that our competitors, particularly the EEC and the United States which have high levels of protection, do not have to pay those costs. So not only do they have a very high level of protection, which is a transfer from the taxpayer to the farm sector in those coutnries, but also they do not have the burden that we have of a high level of input costs.

We must get the cost burden down so that our industries can compete. The answer does not lie in going down the tariff route. The tariff route means a transfer from one industry or one individual to another. In the long term that will exacerbate the problem and probably lead Australia into a position where our industries will suffer the same level of attrition as industries in the EC and United States.

Part of the answer lies in the modernisation of our meat industry. Meat inspection costs in other countries are in the order of 40 or 50 per cent less than they are in Australia. One could talk about this for a significant length of time—I do not intend to do so—but I will say that in dealing with meat inspection costs one must also recognise that that is not the only area where cost structure and cost problems have to be addressed. Despite the Harrison report and all we have heard in this chamber about industrial reform in our meat industry, our killing costs are between three to two to one and a half times that of other countries, depending on whom we compare ourselves with in terms of the world situation.

I emphasise the importance of the removal of input taxes on Australian farmers, as outlined in the Fightback package. I want to emphasise the point that the introduction of tariff regimes, particularly when one is trying to relate them to industries pertinent to the upcoming by-election, is just a straight transfer from one industry or one individual to another in terms of consumer tax. However, the biggest flaw in all this is that it means that somebody is trying to pick winners. There is no evidence to suggest that when it comes to being world competitive, one can actually decide that a particular industry should be protected and that another should not. What inevitably happens is that the protected industries get into a cocoon and become inefficient and too cosy with the position they are in.

As previous speakers have said, the Opposition is supporting these Bills. I finalise my comments by saying that, while the changes to this Bill are desirable and welcome, as is usual with Bills relating to agriculture, not enough emphasis in the current debate is placed on the importance of getting our costs down in the farming sector. We should be making our meat inspection service and our meat slaughter systems, or abattoirs, competitive and effective by removing input taxes, which are an enormous burden on the Australian farming sector. I also emphasise the importance of not turning the clock back on tariffs and having the $8,000 per farm increase again when it should be decreasing at a very rapid rate.
