TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Is this your farewell speech, by the way?

TALK.START.PARA: —Not yet, Mr Acting Deputy President. It will come in due course. The Migration Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1991 proposes to amend the Migration Act 1958 to make changes to the merits review system, distinguish the power to detain a person under the Act, increase certain penalty provisions in line with Commonwealth criminal law policy, allow consistent application of pecuniary penalties under the Crimes Act 1914, and provide that the obligation to endorse a visa or entry permit will be satisfied by an endorsement being recorded in a notified database.

PARA.TAB: The coalition has no difficulty or problem with these amendments. The changes to the review system ensure that its objectives of fairness and speed in decisions continue, and the changes to the level of penalties for offences under the Act change the formula under which the maximum pecuniary penalties are imposed.

It is sensible to tidy up the references to powers of arrest so that they are changed to read, `detain in custody', and so that no confusion remains over the restrictions of arrest as set out in the Crimes Act 1914. The maximum pecuniary penalty for an illegal immigrant escaping from custody will rise from $5,000 to $12,000. We welcome this as evidence that the growing problem of illegal immigrants is being taken seriously by the Government.

The amendment which changes an obvious marked endorsement on a visa or entry permit of someone suffering from, for example, a prescribed physical or medical condition to a simple record on a departmental database is also sensible in its desire to preserve privacy and negate any potential for embarrassment. Accordingly, we support the Bill, which has these and other minor technical amendments which are aimed at smoothing the operations of the immigration Department in its implementation of migration legislation.

However, I feel it should go on record at this point that we on this side of the chamber remain totally frustrated by the Government's inability to look at the big picture of immigration problems and act accordingly. Instead, it deals with a steady stream of bandaid legislation and a multitude of regulations which appear to change hourly—never mind daily. That creates confusion for not only the legislators but also the departmental staff located throughout this country and overseas who attempt to abide by the Act and the regulations. The constant change that we have seen over recent times leads only to confusion, uncertainty and frustration at officer level; that, in turn, has an impact on individuals seeking advice from departmental officers as to the Act, the regulations, its implementation and its effect on individuals.

I hope that the Government at least concedes, acknowledges and recognises that it has a major problem with this Act and the multitude of regulations and it is not attempting to come to grips with that problem in a meaningful way. Rather, there is this host of regulations—bandaid upon bandaid upon bandaid—that is creating confusion. I trust and hope that the Government will recognise that that is a problem and act in a more decisive way to overcome those problems that are clearly in this Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that I speak after my South Australian colleague Senator Olsen. I very much support his summation of the Migration Amendment Bill (No.4) 1991. In fact, the clauses are capable of bipartisan support in this chamber because they strengthen legislation in the national interest. This debate gives the Senate an opportunity to discuss the Government's immigration policies. I wish to briefly draw attention to two major areas of weakness in the administration of immigration by this Government.

PARA.TAB: I first want to note that there has been too much change, too much reworking of regulations, in the past three years since I was a member of the parliamentary committee set up to review migration regulations. There has been enormous complication and variation because of the changes that have been introduced. The Government got a lot of things wrong and it has been too slow in making the repairs necessary to make the Act work.

The reason why we refer to regulations in this area so much is that for the new Act to work, it requires a huge volume of subsidiary legislation which is in the form of regulations; that is, not provisions which are directly debated in the Parliament but provisions which are formulated and published by the Government with advice from the Parliament's Joint Committee on Migration Regulations, subject to a possible disallowance by Parliament. So the regulations under the Migration Act are now enormously complicated and enormously detailed, and, as I say, in these recent years we have been enormously taxing upon the thousands of public servants who are required to administer the Act and the regulations through the volume of changes that have been necessary because the Government did not get it right in the beginning.

There are two matters in Migration Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1991 that I want to refer to. One is the new section 121A. I welcome the amendment. It makes clearer the situation which will be followed when a case is being reviewed; that is, where an applicant has been denied immigration and is then appealing for a review of the original decision. The regulations to be taken into account when an appeal is being considered are to be those which are the more beneficial to the applicant, whether they be those in effect at the time of the first decision on the case or those applying when the appeal is under consideration. That appears to be just. It certainly is to the advantage of the applicant. So this clarification by that amendment is one that I welcome.

I refer, as Senator Olsen did, to the updating of the penalty provisions in the Act. It happens that penalties in Acts can go unreviewed for a period and, after a while, can become out of date. It is therefore desirable that this Bill addresses the matter of penalties in the Migration Act and seeks to bring them into line with the general approach of the Commonwealth to penalties in criminal law as set out in section 4B(2) of the Crimes Act. The increase in the level of financial penalties emphasises the seriousness with which the Parliament views breaches of the Migration Act.

Maintaining the integrity of our immigration policy is a recurring theme of mine. I think anyone who wanted to bother himself would find that in a dozen speeches on immigration here in the Senate in recent years the integrity of the immigration program is something that I have referred to on every occasion. I believe that the Australian public does not have confidence in the present Government's administration of immigration. It does not have confidence that we do have an immigration program that has integrity. It seems to be not fair to all comers from wherever they may apply. It seems to me to be one of the essential goals that we all should press towards—whether from the Australian Democrats, from the present Government or from the future government. We should so back up the legislation, the decisions of this chamber and the other in the Parliament, and so enact, fairly in every part of the world, the immigration regulations, that people applying to come to live in Australia could be assured that they are being dealt with in exactly the same way, whether their applications came from one country or another, and so that the whole system of immigration decisions had a ring of integrity about it.

There are two present concerns of mine that I now wish to refer to which go beyond this increase in the penalties that are required to ensure that there is a deterrent for those who are breaking our immigration laws. I certainly welcome the increase in the penalties. I certainly welcome the increased signal this gives that we are intent about a deterrent to those who would break Australian law in the immigration area and that we are seeking to have integrity for our immigration program.

But the two major elements undermining the soundness of our immigration program are squarely at the feet of the present Labor Government here in Canberra. One is the result of the present recession. It appears that when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was Treasurer, he regarded Australia as needing a recession. He certainly has been the one most responsible for the recession that we have: one million unemployed; a $160 billion national debt; a huge current account problem; a country that is going broke; and suffering in every State and every city and area of Australia. In the context of this recession, the Government has not adjusted the immigration program to take account of the recession that it has placed upon Australians.

I share with those in the Opposition a call even now for the Government to cut the immigration program so that we do not have applicants coming from various countries, immigrating to Australia with high hopes that they will make a new world for themselves, a new world of prosperity for their family and a contribution to this country, only to find that when they arrive there is a degree of recession that they had not expected and that they are on the dole queue, that they are unemployed and that their dreams are shattered, and that they are not only adding to the burden on the Australian taxpayer, but also they are themselves the victims of being lured to immigrate to a country that at the moment does not have a huge amount to offer them.

For all of my 14 years in the Senate I have advocated high immigration—but always a responsibly high amount. I have seen immigration since the Second World War as one of the factors that has led to the economic development of this country. I say `responsibly high' because the figure must be a number which Australia is able to integrate successfully. If we had so great a number of immigrants that we were not capable as an economy and as a social community of ensuring that they made a transition into fully productive and prosperous families within Australia, then the number would be too high. I, as someone who wants a high immigration program in normal times, am calling for a lower immigration figure because it is irresponsible to add to the dole queues and to add to the misery of victims of a recession, those who have newly arrived in this country.

The Government has recently been urged by the ACTU to cut the immigration program by 10 per cent—by, I think, some 11,000. When I read Mr Ferguson's remarks—and, of course, the trade unions are very close allies of the Government; some of my colleagues regard them as the real government of Australia—I saw that the ACTU is putting forward the view that this Government has been too slow to recognise that in a recession there is a need to cut the numbers.

Only this week the trade unions called for this change and made this direct criticism of the immigration program as administered by the Labor Government. What they are calling for is, itself, too late and too little. I still urge the Government to cut the immigration numbers by more than the amount that the ACTU is now urging but, frankly, for much the same reason that the ACTU has mentioned.

I notice the advisers to the Government are in the chamber. We have looked at each other across the chamber on many occasions when dealing with immigration matters. I say to them and to all those in the public who are—

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening in with bated breath!

—That is right. In order to ensure the integrity of our immigration program as a successful program, a reliable program, and one that people can build their lives upon when making decisions to come to this country; and in order not to create further victims of the recession beyond the one million Australians who are unemployed; we need to cut the immigration numbers much more than the ACTU has advocated this week.

PARA.TAB: I draw attention to two other elements of the ACTU's recommendations. The first is to emphasise English language requirements in the intake of those successful applicants for immigration to Australia. It was fashionable about five to 10 years ago amongst the members of the present Government to downgrade the test of English language requirements because they were supposing that this was an indirect way of discriminating against those whose mother tongue was not English but some other language—as if it was some small shadow of the old and now totally discarded White Australia policy.

The Labor Party performed a disservice when its ranks took up that fashion five to 10 years ago. We all need to look squarely at the practical elements of those applicants who are coming to Australia and to note, very honestly, that it is a requirement for success in this country to be fluent in English. Priority ought to be given to those applicants who have English language as a skill that equips them to be more successful when they come to this country.

We do have adult and child migrant English education programs, but that is only to ensure that those who come, having won priority for other reasons, cannot be disadvantaged in their actual lives here in Australia. We give them the bridge to gain English language abilities when they are here. But, in the program itself, we need to give greater weight to English language as a requirement for successful application. I note as well that it is skills—marketable, employable skills—that go beyond English language as the requirement that ought to gain priority for applicants when they are applying to immigrate to Australia.

We want to see the immigration program work not only to the advantage of those successful applicants who want to come and live in this country but also, very clearly, to the advantage of Australia's national interest. Those that will have the best economic effect upon this country from the immigration program are those who come here with well developed skills—with expertise—that they will then use to the betterment of this country. Again, we need to go right back to the Fitzgerald report, to a whole range of signals in the last five years, to get the balance more weighted in favour of skilled migration to this country to the benefit of all Australians.

Having directly criticised the Government with regard to the effect of the recession and the need to cut immigration, I finally turn to the vexed problem of the Chinese students in Australia before and since the Tiananmen Square massacre of June 1989. There has been some disastrous news this month, and that is the revealing by the Government in answer to Opposition questions of a total blow-out of numbers in the overstay of Chinese students in this country.

I am the Vice President in this Parliament of the Australia-China Friendship Association. I have visited China on numerous occasions. Honourable senators will know that I was one who advocated in February last year the normalising of relations between Australia and China to the benefit of both of our countries. But I am equally strong in my remarks about the integrity of Australia's immigration program. I am equally emphatic that, when overseas students come to study in Australia, they do so on the basis that they will gain skills and return to use those skills in their own country.

In the case of China, we have had tens of thousands of students who have come, studied in Australia, gained professional skills as well as English language reinforcements and gone back to serve in China—except for those who, by this present Labor Government, have been given an easy road, a short cut. I believe it was an unsound decision that they should be able to remain in Australia despite the undertaking they gave that they would return to China, and despite Australia's alleged commitment to an overseas student program which would return students to their own countries.

The bad news of this month is this: we all knew about a first group, that is, some 21,000 Chinese students who were in Australia at the time of the Tiananmen Square massacre in June 1989. Many of us were critical, but we understood the emotions that had swayed the hearts of those in the Government to give a blanket extension of visas to those 21,000 students for four years, in order to work out whether or not they were to gain refugee status in this country or whether they would, in some other way, become permanent residents of Australia.

Since that time about 2,000 of those students have left Australia and 19,000 of that group are still here. The bad news this month is that since the Tiananmen Square massacre, 44,644 Chinese nationals arrived in Australia—24,838 of them were students, the others were non-students—and only 16,382 of these have left, only 2,125 of them being students. That leaves a balance of 28,262 who are overstaying. These overstayers are not the students who were here when the Tiananmen Square massacre happened; they are Chinese citizens who have arrived since the massacre.
So we have two groups. The total of the two groups is not just 19,000 of the original group, but the total of 47,262 who remain in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Illegally.

—Some of them are here illegally, but most of them are here because of the soft-heartedness of the present Government. The soft-hearted announcement of the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, was made without consultation with the Minister for Immigration at the time and the Department.
—That was only because of Tiananmen Square.

—It was made because the former Prime Minister was in tears about the possible suffering or discrimination that those students might experience on their return to China. So, without consultation and without addressing his mind to the repercussions that this would have in undermining the integrity of the Australian immigration program, by a wave of the arm—literally—an extension of visas was granted to all those students. Because it is hard to differentiate the present situation of those who have arrived since the Tiananmen Square massacre from the situation of those who arrived before it, the wave of the arm applies to them as well.

PARA.TAB: So almost 50,000 Chinese residents have, by a wave of the arm, gained residence in Australia. For some it will be temporary residence, but that is still to be seen. The Government has not delivered. The Government has not clarified what will happen with regard to these 50,000 Chinese students.

I do not want to go on too long about this. I would rather sit down and allow other senators to speak on this immigration Bill. I just want to make it entirely clear that if there is a genuine refugee amongst those 50,000—that is, a person who can demonstrate that his or her life or livelihood would be in jeopardy were he or she required to return to China—Australia can respond as it does to every other genuine refugee in Australia.

It is not only my estimate but also, I believe, the estimate of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and of Chinese students themselves that at least 95 per cent of the 50,000 I have referred to would not jeopardise their lives or livelihoods were they to return to China.

I have advocated since June 1989 that there be a case-by-case review of the applicants by an administrative method which did not require one person laboriously going over 50,000 applications but which instead, in a properly systematic way, dealt with categories of applicants expeditiously. It was my hope that it would be all completely determined by now. However, this Government is out of control. It has not made any hard decisions in this matter. It is still relying upon former Prime Minister Hawke's wave of the arm. This is a totally unresolved element of Australia's immigration program.

It is a signal going to all parts of the world that if people who get to Australia have some kind of excuse on which to build a refugee application, they should go for their lives for they may be able to succeed. If they employ private sector lawyers, they can at least delay through appeals and get an extended stay and, even if they lose, they get a couple of years of all the benefits of living in Australia.

The Australian public does not have confidence in the present Labor Government's administration of immigration. It does not have confidence either on the recession grounds to which I referred or on the complete blow-out with regard to the Chinese students in this country. I wish every individual Chinese student well in his or her future. I hope most of them return to their country and contribute positively to it without any kind of deterrent or impediment to their professional work there.

I will not table here some correspondence I have received in the last few weeks, which I am sure the Department is very aware of, from Chinese students who are writing to members of parliament saying, `Let me make it clear. I know my community. The reason 50,000 Chinese want to stay in Australia is exactly the same as the reason everyone else wants to stay in Australia—they love the place. They think it is a way to have a better life. They like the affluence of Australia. They want to make their lives here because their children will have a better future in this country than if they returned to the Third World comforts of China'.

I am not denying their aspiration to live in Australia. Of course I recognise that so many who are here illegally or in undetermined status would love to remain in Australia. But so do about 50 million people in the world. The whole point of an immigration program is to ensure that there is fairness, integrity and a rational determination of the priorities of applicants—and the same outcome for an applicant from one country as from another. That is what is smelling at the moment. That is what is not happening.

Why does not the present Government recognise the equal claims by the Lebanese, the Filipinos, the English, the Germans, the Irish and every other kind of applicant who wants to live in Australia and who recognises that this is a great place for their children and a place where they can make a contribution? I am not in any way questioning the aspirations of the 50,000 Chinese, but I am seriously critical of the present Government's inability to make the decisions that are needed to ensure that there is integrity in Australia's immigration program.

TALK.START.PARA: —And at such length.

—I say this with such emphasis because I have already done so four or five times in immigration debates in this chamber—and the Government still has not made a decision. I can only conclude by saying that this Government seems to be paralysed in regard to making decisions to ensure the integrity of the immigration program. (Time expired)

—The Australian Democrats also support the substance of the Migration Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1991, which is to clarify and make fairer the administration of the way Australia deals with those people who have come into the country, who may come into the country or who may not be able to remain in the country. We strongly support the increased fairness and clarity with which these matters are to be dealt.

PARA.TAB: I reflect the remarks of Senator Baden Teague, who has just spoken, in this regard and stress that the Democrats would always support any move to make those matters clearer, fairer and less restrictive. They should also be applied equally to people who come from any part of the world. There should be no discrimination on the grounds of race, sex, religion or any of those other things built into our immigration system.

However, Senator Baden Teague made some remarks about the aspect of immigration relating to numbers. He, like his Leader and the ACTU, calls for a reduction in the size of the immigration program. I would like to direct a few remarks to that question.

The Democrats adopted in 1977, and have been working out in considerably more detail, what it means for Australia to move towards an ecologically sustainable pattern of development for future generations who live in this country, from wherever they may come. The options in terms of the environment and availability of resources will be no less than the options which are available to the present generation. That is, after all, what sustainability means; it is what inter-generational equity, on which sustainability is based, ultimately means.

Both the Government and the Opposition have paid lip-service to the idea of sustainability, but have failed totally to recognise that the size of the population which is acting on the environment is one major component of that impact; and that, before one has an immigration program at all, one needs to develop a population policy. That is something that this country has totally failed to do. We have had an immigration program now since 1947; we have never, as a nation, developed a population policy.

In terms of sustainability, I think it is manifest to everybody that the pattern of exploitation in Australia is not sustainable in the long run. We are degrading the ability of our land to produce food; we have increasing soil erosion; we have increasing salinisation; and we are decreasing the ability of this country's water supply to continue to meet the needs of even the present population. We have seen our water supplies become increasingly polluted. We have seen in the last year the spread of blue-green algae into the Murray-Darling system on which Adelaide ultimately depends for its backup water supply. We have seen, in the case of Perth, the gradual rundown of the aquifers underlying that city and on which its water supply depends, and we have seen progressive pollution of those aquifers. We have seen increasing salinisation of those aquifers as they become both polluted and depressed, because Perth, after all, is built on a very sandy coastal plain.

All those things indicate that if the present population of this country continues to make the demands on the environment which it currently does, the environment will not be sustainable. In other words, we are, by that measure of sustainability, already an over-populated country. That is why we need desperately to develop a population policy. We need to try to work out at what level of resource use—at what level of impact in terms of demand for resources and the pollution consequent upon the exploitation and the disposal of those resources—we can maintain an industrial civilisation in this country over the long term.

Having worked out that level per capita, then what size of population is consistent with that, bearing in mind that we are committed to ensuring, I hope, that there will be a viable and worthwhile lifestyle still present for our descendants in this country—not in 10 years time or in 50 years time, but in 1,000 years time, in 10,000 years time and in one million years time; that people will still be able to inhabit this country without loss of the quality of life which we have come to enjoy and on which, ultimately, the welfare of human beings as animals depends. One of the most depressing aspects of the migration reviews which go on is that we do not find biologists and ecologists built into that review process.

I make an appeal to the Government to develop, as a matter of urgency, a population policy. It must look quite seriously at the changes in the demography of the Australian population. It must look at what is happening to the age structure of the Australian population; what is happening to that age structure if we have substantial increases in immigration rates for some years and then, for whatever reason, we substantially cut those rates.

What happens in that event is that we have a cohort of people who move through the population all ageing at the same time and we produce the very problems that many people have argued we need to avoid in terms of an excessive number of ageing people in the community not supported by a sufficient number of young people. It is, as it were, a reverse of the situation we had after the Second World War when we had a baby boom. Suddenly we found that we had to build a lot of schools, which a few years later were empty. We had made a large investment in resources which were then being under-utilised. When those baby-boomers themselves produced children, we had another mini baby boom, and we had a damped recurrence of the same thing. We needed to build more facilities for child education which a few years down the track were not required. In a similar way, if we have a cohort of people who all age together, not followed on by another cohort of people of roughly the same size, we will build a lot of facilities for aged people which then in a few years time we will not need.

So the call which has come from some members of the Opposition for a complete cessation of immigration simply does not take into account those sorts of factors. If we are going to build a population policy, we must look at that policy over a very long period. It cannot be a short term policy. Because people live 70 to 80 years, a population policy has to look at what will happen over at least 100 years.

To put a few figures to this, what will happen to Australia's population under various possible scenarios? It is often and quite incorrectly said that if we were to cut our immigration rate to zero now, our population would immediately start falling simply because the net reproduction rate of Australians is below one, below replacement. That conclusion is totally false and ignores the fact that the majority of the Australian population is younger than a population at stability. We have more young women still to enter their reproductive years than we have older women who are dying.

So, without any immigration at all into this country, population would still increase by about three million people and then would go into slow decline, if the net reproduction rate remained at about 0.9, where it is now. But it would not get back to 17 million people until about 100 years from now. So the idea that the population would suddenly fall because we had no immigration is simply false and is not borne out by demographic analysis. Similarly, when the former Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, was asked what he thought an optimal population for Australia might be, he gave the figure of 25 million. That is a figure which many other people have used.

The present rates of immigration would see us pass 25 million and wave goodbye to it around the year 2,030 with no hope of ever getting back to it. If we want to stabilise at about 25 million people, we need to cut quite seriously the present immigration rate. So I make the point that we need to develop a population policy for this country and, having done that, to look at what sort of immigration program in terms of numbers would fit with that population policy.

I stress again that the Democrats in no sense blame immigrants for any environmental damage which has occurred in this country; it is not the immigrants who are responsible for the immigration program; it is the Government. If the increase in population causes environmental problems, it is the Government which has caused the population increase by pursuing a program of population increase through immigration. Migrants are not responsible for environmental damage. Similarly, those who do come into this country should never be selected on any grounds which relate to race, religion, creed, sex or any other discriminatory factor.

Where we would differ very markedly from both the Government and the Opposition is in meeting our humanitarian responsibilities. We believe that the immigration program should be based around refugees, and around family reunion. It should not be about skills, or a reconstructed business migration program—if that should get under way. Skills have been used as an argument for immigration to this country ever since 1947. It is an indictment of successive governments in this country that apparently we still need skilled people to come into this country. We should have a much better educational and training program in this country for Australians, so that we do not need to bring in people with skills from outside. It is about time we trained Australians more adequately, so that we do not feel a need to bring in people from other countries. In relation to business migration, certainly as it was constructed, I think enough has been said about the rorts and the damage which that program did.

In terms of refugees, I pick up a remark of Senator Baden Teague where he quite clearly identified refugees as being those people who temporarily cannot remain in their own country for fear of action being taken against them which threatens their life or their livelihood. The Democrats believe that Australia should bring in a much larger number of refugees, bearing in mind that they may well be people who later on could return to their own country, but in the meantime need succour. As far as the family reunion program is concerned, it is obvious that having brought people into this country, it is only fair that those people at least should be allowed to bring close family into Australia. I would argue that the program does need to be cut, but cut along lines which are based on long term sustainability.

DEBATE.TITLE: COARSE GRAINS LEVY BILL 1992[COGNATE BILL:COARSE GRAINS LEVY (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1992]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 March, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest that the Coarse Grains Levy Bill 1992 be debated cognately with the Coarse Grains Levy (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1992.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for a single Act imposing levies on coarse grains for the purpose of funding research. The Bill incorporates the existing barley and triticale levies and extends the coverage of coarse grains to oats and cereal rye. The levies will attract matching Commonwealth contributions as provided for under the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development (PIERD) Act 1989.

These arrangements are being implemented at the request of the Grains Council of Australia (GCA) on behalf of coarse grain producers after consultations with other relevant industry bodies, including the Triticale Grain Association of Australia which is the representative industry body under the Triticale Levy Act 1988. The GCA is currently the representative industry body for barley and has been nominated as such for oats and cereal rye.

To date, barley and triticale research levies have been imposed under separate Acts which, in the main, are only differentiated by product specific provisions. The oats and cereal rye levy arrangements will be similar. Consequently, omnibus levy legislation has been developed covering these grains with provision for other coarse grains to be added by regulation having regard to any recommendation of the relevant growers' organisation.

The Barley Research Levy Act 1980 and the Triticale Levy Act 1988 will be repealed under the related Coarse Grains Levy (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1992, which includes provisions to ensure continuity of current levy arrangements for these grains.

Implementing research levies for oats and cereal rye represents an extension of the Government's policy of encouraging increased contributions by primary industry for rural research which was established in 1985. The Government made a commitment to continue matching expenditure of approved industry levies on a dollar for dollar basis up to 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production (GVP) of the relevant industry. This policy was reaffirmed in the May 1989 Government statement, "Research Innovation and Competitiveness".

With regard to the new crops to be levied, oats production has, in recent seasons, varied between 1.4 and 1.6 million tonnes per year with the gross value of production averaging $172 million in the three years to 1991/92. Production is centred mainly in Western Australia (estimated at 32 per cent in 1991/92), New South Wales (28 per cent), Victoria (19 per cent) and South Australia (19 per cent).

The greater proportion of the oats crop—an estimated 72 per cent in 1991/92—is used on the domestic market where oats have long been an important supplement to the successful operation of grazing enterprises involving sheep and cattle. Oats are used either as a grazing supplement and for fodder reserves, or for the production of hay and silage. Export sales of grain, which average around 220,000 tonnes annually, are also an important outlet which is expected to earn around $32 million in 1991/92.

In addition to these benefits, the production and consumption of milling oats, used for human consumption, has been expanding as a result of increased demand for health products which has created an opportunity to expand oats markets both in Australia and overseas.
The cereal rye industry is small but has the capacity to expand its domestic market, particularly in the health food market where more research and promotion is desirable.

Australian production of approximately 20,000 tonnes per annum is concentrated in the mallee regions of Victoria and South Australia. Although production is small, it plays an important role in overall farm management. Cereal rye is one of the few cropping alternatives for the mallee sandhills, not only allowing producers to obtain an economic return from land that may otherwise be left idle but also preventing erosion and stabilising these soils.

The demand for cereal rye in Australia has centred around the consumption of rye-based bread, biscuits and breakfast cereals. The recent upsurge in food and lifestyle awareness has resulted in a major upswing in the interest in, and demand for, health foods. Overall demand for rye has not always been satisfied from domestic production necessitating imports in recent years which peaked at 10,000 tonnes in 1989/90.

Research funding for oats and cereal rye has in the past been obtained from a combination of Commonwealth and State Government and industry sources such as the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation (and its predecessor the Australian Special Rural Research Council), CSIRO, State agriculture departments and universities. However, funding under these programs has not been sufficient to allow these industries to address adequately the range of research and development issues confronting them.

The establishment of joint Commonwealth/ industry research schemes for oats and cereal rye will broaden the research funding base for these industries and assist in enabling them to achieve their full potential, not only on the domestic front but also from an export perspective.

The operative levy rates for barley and triticale will remain unchanged at $0.75 per tonne and $1.00 per tonne respectively. However, with the agreement of the prescribed grower organisations, the Bill provides for these rates to be increased by regulation up to a maximum of $5.00 per tonne.

Initially, the operative levy rates for oats and cereal rye will be 0.5 per cent of the value of the grain with provision for these to be increased by regulation up to a maximum of 5 per cent of the value of the grain. The manner in which the sales value of the grain will be ascertained for levy purposes will be set out in regulations, following further consultations with industry.

The introduction of value-based levies for oats and cereal rye at the request of the GCA reflects the Council's policy of relating the amount of levy payable more directly to the return received by the producer. A value-based levy has applied to wheat since 1989.
For all coarse grains, operative rates of levies may be increased by regulation only after consideration of any recommendations to the Minister by relevant grower organisations.
The levies relating to each of the coarse grains involved will be payable by the producer of that grain and collected in accordance with the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991.

Administrative and organisational arrangements for the research schemes will be the responsibility of the Grains Research and Development Corporation (GRDC). Amounts equal to the individual levies and the Commonwealth's matching contributions will be paid into separate accounts under the management of the GRDC. The Corporation is required under its enabling legislation to account separately for expenditure of levy revenue derived from each type of grain.

Additional expenditure resulting from the extension of matching Commonwealth funding to oats and cereal rye will not commence before 1993/94. At the proposed levy rate of 0.5 per cent of the value of the grain, matching Commonwealth contributions for 1993/94 are estimated at approximately $250,000 for oats and $20,000 for cereal rye. The cost to the budget of Commonwealth matching contributions for the existing barley and triticale schemes is estimated at $3.1 million and $90,000 respectively for 1992/93. Similar outlays are expected in 1993/94.
The Bill will commence on 1 October 1992 to coincide with the commencement of the crop year for all grains involved.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Coarse Grains Levy Bill 1992 is to impose a levy on barley, cereal rye, oats and triticale in Australia to fund research. The purpose of the Coarse Grains Levy (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1992 is to provide for the collection of levies on the barley, triticale, oats and cereal rye industries and to repeal the Barley Research Levy Act 1980 and the Triticale Levy Act 1988. With reference to the Coarse Grains Levy Bill 1992, coarse grains comprise feed wheat, triticale, sorghum, feed oats, feed maize and barley. Together, coarse grains constitute Australia's second most important crop after wheat. Barley, at $708m in 1989-90; oats, at $178m; and sorghum, at $136m, rank among Australia's top income earners.

PARA.TAB: This Bill proposes to incorporate the existing barley and triticale levies imposed by the Barley Research Levy Act 1980 and the Triticale Levy Act 1988 in a single Act and impose new levies on oats and cereal rye. These proposed levy arrangements are being made at the request of the Coarse Grains Council of Australia, on behalf of coarse grain producers.

This legislation is part of the standard rural industry research and development arrangement through the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989, that is, the dollar for dollar industry and government arrangement up to a maximum of 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production for the particular industry. It is estimated that the Commonwealth's matching contribution for oats and cereal rye will total $270,000 per annum from 1993-94, and $3.1m for barley and $90,000 for triticale in 1992-93.

Turning to the Coarse Grains Levy (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1992, the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991, the principal Act, provides uniform collection procedures for various levies and charges. Prior to the commencement of the principal Act, each primary industry levy and charge comprised two pieces of legislation, an Act imposing the levy and/or charge and an Act collecting the levy or charge.

One of the principal effects of the principal Act was to do away with the levy or charge collection Act for each levy of charge imposed. However, Acts which impose a levy or charge are not able to be consolidated in the same way as collection Acts because of section 55 of the Constitution, part of which provides:

SPEECH.PARA: Laws imposing taxation, except laws imposing duties of customs or of excise, shall deal with one subject of taxation only;. . .

The provisions of the principal Act largely reflect standard Commonwealth levy and charge collection legislation of the past five years, and update many of the collection arrangements for levies and charges imposed by those Acts listed in the schedules to the principal Act.

PARA.TAB: With regard to coarse grains and grain research, this legislation signifies further development in the coarse grains and grain industry generally, which can be seen in three stages. The first stage was when wheat, alone of the grains, had a research arrangement with the Government. Over a period, that was seen to be too narrow. The concentration was on wheat when there was a need for research to develop more appropriate strains of other coarse grain varieties to meet market opportunities and also as required for better farm management practices in the wheat-sheep zone of Australia.

The second stage in the development of research arrangements came with the inclusion of that broader range of grain varieties in the research arrangements. In this second stage, yield, as well as suitable varieties for different climatic and soil situations, was the dominant factor. The third stage is where the yield is still important but market requirements are now having a higher priority than before.

The Opposition parties will be supporting this legislation. We acknowledge the progress that is being made with coarse grain research and recognise that there is now a need for more special research to pick up these market opportunities. At a time when coarse grain growers of Australia are experiencing their lowest incomes on record—according to the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, it is $32,000 on a farm business basis—and the uncertainties and unfairness of a corrupt world grain trade, these farmers are really setting an example to the rest of Australia.

In this particularly difficult economic time, these growers are prepared not only to meet the standard or the challenge set for them by government of 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production but also to go beyond it. If other sectors of Australian business were prepared to make the same sacrifices for long term gains for the international competitiveness of their industry, Australia would be looking forward to a far better future.

TALK.START.PARA: —The idea of the Coarse Grain Levy Bill is to bring together in one Bill certain different Acts and to impose a levy on oats. I welcome the measure because there is a wide variety of coarse grains. I have a certain amount of experience in coarse grains, so I had better declare my interest, since I generally forget to do that in these cases. It would be far more organised if we could bring the wheat industry under one roof. I can see that oats, barley, triticale and rye would come in.

PARA.TAB: I believe that in the past the coarse grains have been rather neglected, but not so much on the levy side. We have had a levy on quite a few of them for research, but the money spent on research here, of course, varies with production and production, of course, varies with world markets. Coarse grains, unfortunately, react to what the wheat industry does. If the wheat prices keep up at a certain level, coarse grains go down. So the industry is not able to make any real long term contracts. I know that oats is in fair demand for malting overseas, as well as barley, but getting that reaction caused by the wheat price going up and down really does not let the coarse grains settle down.

The most stable sort of market is within Australia itself and that is mostly with the stockfeeders. They are making stockfeed and manufacturing stockfeed for animals—racehorses and that sort of thing. Then, of course, that being a limited market, it gives a limited price. I know oats has been static at $100 a tonne for the last 10 years—as far as I can remember—and then for that it has to be delivered to the city as well.

Another thing about oats is that no really new varieties of high production have been round for quite a time, especially for the low rainfall areas. With the sorts of levies that will be going through, matched by the government contribution, hopefully some new varieties of oats that will produce a reasonably high return in the low rainfalls, as well as the high rainfalls, will be developed.

Production in high rainfalls is quite high, but where we have that sort of case we want more research to be done on producing grain without producing too much bulk in the straw. Bulk in the straw is very good for those who happen to be growing hay and selling hay as a product, but, unfortunately, with the sorts of varieties that are around there is too much bulk in the straw and by the time it is the right sort of weather to cut hay, it goes rank. So the industry needs an oats to be developed with not too much bulk, enough bulk to cut hay without getting too rank, and, of course, a return.

The departments of agriculture, especially of Western Australia, have been at the forefront of research into coarse grains, but I believe that it is not repeated around the rest of Australia. By the same token, I would say that some States lead the research into the wheat industry, especially South Australia, where a reasonably high grade quality of wheat has been developed which also has a production. It does not do the economics of a farm much good by producing quality, and quality alone, if there is no production. The formula has to be worked out so that there is a certain amount of return and that is where I believe the South Australian Department of Agriculture and Roseworthy Agricultural College especially have done a good job.

Getting back to the mechanics of the Bill, I think it is a move in the right direction. Going back some time ago, I can remember that there was no levy with oats, but there was a voluntary levy and this is obviously replacing that. It was almost compulsory in the fact that a box had to be marked and I suppose the oats industry got quite a bit of money through levies that they really got by default. Of course, that caused ups and downs in the amount of levy that came through and, coupled with an up and down production, no-one really knew where they were. This Bill, and the Government putting up a dollar for dollar, will make quite a difference to the stability of research which has got to be encouraged in all products, let alone the coarse grain industry.

If time allows, I will go into a few of the other problems of the rural industry around Australia that exist at the present moment. I have said in this place for quite some time that the rural industry is reviving a certain amount because of the upsurge in wheat prices again, but there are a lot of other aspects that this Government has to look at. In the One Nation package, the Government said that it would in machinery legislation provide certain measures to help out the rural industry. We have not had the legislation, but I think it is too little and, in many cases, too late.

There was a certain amount of money for RAS, that is, the rural adjustment scheme. It is called RAFCOR in Western Australia and it is very slow in putting any money out that it may have because it is set up with a bureaucratic sort of system. The money goes to RAFCOR, which then decides how to distribute it and applications are made. These applications are made by farmers needing carry-on finance or finance to build the farm up—or, indeed, there is a certain amount of finance available to help the ones that have no future get off the farm altogether.

I presume that one can compare that to the pay-out on the Australian waterfront. The only thing is that this Government prefers to help its waterfront mates more than farmers, because its waterfront mates have had security of tenure in their jobs for many years, with guaranteed pay for a maximum of 35 weeks. They still get their pay, whether they work for five weeks or 35 weeks. In Senator Collins's buy-out package, there is an average of $94,000 available to buy out their jobs.

Further to that, even though the waterfront reform is going along quite smoothly, as Senator Collins tells us, the Western Australian State Government has bought into the argument by directing its port authorities to take on some of these excess waterfront workers as permanent employees—permanent employees but still with their same old conditions under that big package, which is a salary of about $50,000 to $60,000 per year, a maximum of 35 hours per week, with no minimum, five weeks holiday pay and all that sort of thing. These regional ports have been forced to take these people on.

Getting back to the Bill again, that sort of arrangement keeps up the costs to get those coarse grains, as well as wheat, across the wharf. What is more, these extras that the port authorities have been told to take on are not needed. What is the use of watching a self-loading ship load or a self-unloading ship unload? It is totally pointless. In that case, if the Government of Western Australia, or indeed any other State government, had any interest for the wheat industry, the coarse grain industry or any other industry, it would not buy into the argument and go down the line of pushing wharfage up rather than down. The figures that I have for the waterfront of Sydney and Melbourne show that costs to put goods across the wharf have gone up 20 per cent in the last 12 months, whereas they should be going down with this waterfront reform.

On the other side, very little has been done for our grain growers and coarse grain growers. I think that $80m was allocated as extra carry-on finance. I think the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) could instead have looked at the idea of putting that money through the other way by making it available as, say, a one-off GMP, a guaranteed minimum price, for grain. I know that GMP is a dirty word with the Government. The guaranteed minimum price for the wheat industry was taken off by this Government the last time it brought in a new wheat marketing Act.

I no longer advocate a GMP, but I think a GMP, rather than putting more money into RAFCOR or RAS, would have been a lot more efficient because there would not be that backlog that there is with RAFCOR dealing with farmers' needs. A one-off guarantee such as the one Premier Carmel Lawrence put on the wheat industry in Western Australia last year, and which incidentally got the crop planted, would enable the money to go back to the local bank managers, who know farmers and businessmen a lot closer to hand, and would be far more efficient. That is where the Government could have helped. The Government could have helped by implementing other measures to take the imposts off farmers, rather than what it has done.

We got into the tariff debate this morning. The Democrats this morning moved a motion to suspend standing orders to debate tariffs. The only reason they did so, of course, is that this is the last broadcast day in the Senate before the Wills by-election. The rural producers had to cop their tariffs first. It is too late to go back on tariffs; we have to keep going. The Government and the Opposition have the same sort of policy. We have to keep going. The rural producers have taken their hit in the past and it is time that industry took its medicine and became far more efficient.
I support the measures in the Coarse Grain Levy Bill because they will only make for more efficiency in collecting levies in time to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can the Minister for Shipping and Aviation justify the claim that he is achieving waterfront reform in Australia when I have been provided with two quotes: firstly, to ship a 20-foot container loaded with household effects from Hobart to Tilbury, London, at a cost of $A2,000; and, secondly, to ship that same container from Hobart to Brisbane at a cost of $3,500? That is why we introduced the One Nation package and have taken steps to stimulate the economy. What cannot be said of us is that we have ever tried to hide the fact. PARA.TAB: The fact is that fewer than one in 10 Australian teenagers is unemployed and seeking full time work. If we look at the Victorian figures, we find that the figure is a little higher, at 12.1 per cent—but it is not 50 per cent as Senator Patterson's press release has duplicitously alleged in trying to mislead the community.

I refer to the 15- to 19-year-old category. Fewer 15- to 19-year-old people are unemployed in Australia now than were unemployed during the years of the Fraser-Howard recession of 1982-83. I remind the Senate that Dr Hewson was the senior economic adviser to the Fraser Government at that time. TALK.START.PARA: —Read the whole press release.

On the national average, fewer than one of those is unemployed.

PARA.TAB: It is about time that these statistics were treated honestly—not in an alarmist way and not in a way that pretends the problem is different from what it is—so that we can have a genuine debate about the serious problem of youth unemployment in this country.
