Will he comment on the following items in the November 1991 edition of P.M. Observer: first, stories of a sexist and soft-porn nature entitled `Diary of a Private Eye' and `Mistaken Identity'; secondly, a series of blonde jokes—all sexist and many of a degrading soft-porn nature; thirdly, particularly distasteful so-called AIDS jokes; and fourthly, highly discriminatory, offensive and degrading so-called Aboriginal jokes? Is the Minister concerned that the kinds of discriminatory attitudes which have recently been demonstrated in police forces around Australia might also be rampant in the defence establishment, as this publication and other recent events would seem to indicate?
—Any Irish jokes?
—There were some Irish jokes in there too. What steps will the Minister take in relation to this particular publication and on questions of racism and sexism generally in defence establishments?

—I am aware of that publication. It appeared in November 1991. I was asked for my comment and description of it: the publication was sexist, racist and puerile. The commanding officer, having seen that particular publication, took immediate steps to reprimand all involved. I do not think we will see a repeat episode. I was also asked a more general question about whether there is racism and sexism in the defence forces. The answer is, in part, yes, the same as there is in the rest of the community. However, our official attitude is always to counteract those particular tendencies, and I believe that the Australian defence forces have a good record in that regard. One only has to look at Norforce in Northern Australia for an example of proper integration of those of European descent and Aboriginal descent and how well they work together.

PARA.TAB: There are the odd incidents. Another one was mentioned on the SBS news last night. Again, on immediate discovery, full and absolute disciplinary action is taken. We may reach a stage, in this decade or the next, where no-one will exhibit a racist or sexist attitude. I am not confident that that will occur but I can assure the chamber that every time we see signs of this type of behaviour we try to eradicate it, and we will continue to do so.

There are positive sides to it. I receive very favourable comments from other defence Ministers in our region about the behaviour of our various deployments and our crew visits throughout the region, where they are excellent ambassadors for Australia. More often than not, they are better ambassadors than a lot of Australian tourists. I assure the honourable senator that wherever evidence of these sorts of activities is discovered, we try to correct the situation immediately.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his answer and for the information of the prompt action taken by the commanding officer. I ask a supplementary question. Would the Minister take up the question that was raised with me of attitudes and behaviours which have not found their way into print in that establishment? If the Minister could take that up I would appreciate it very much.
—As this issue has only recently come to my attention, I have not yet had a chance to follow through what may be a more general problem than the publication alone. I will follow that matter through.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation. I understand that the Government's reform program for the shipping industry was intended to be finished by June 1992. Is the program running to schedule and will it finish on time?

—I am pleased to advise the Senate that the shipping industry reform program, as demonstrated by the latest progress report, is still running ahead of schedule and will be well and truly completed by the middle of this year. The program has achieved its target of substantially reducing—
—What about cargo to London?

—As a total of only about 3 1/2 per cent of cargo is carried in Australian ships, the chances of that cargo to London being carried in an Australian ship are not very great. The average crew size in Australian ships now stands at 21, representing a cut of 25 per cent over the average of 28 in 1989 and a fall of 36 per cent compared with the 1983 average of 33 when this Government took office. New ships are being introduced now with a crew size down to 17 and 18 and some smaller vessels now have the crew size down to 11. The aim also has been realised of revitalising the Australian fleet by the introduction of modern, technologically-advanced ships.

PARA.TAB: The industry has invested $1.5 billion in 26 new ships over the last three years, representing a renewal of one-third of the total Australian fleet. Another five vessels are on order. I point out, Mr President, that this is the largest capitalisation of the Australian fleet in history and it would never have occurred without the success of the Government's shipping reform program, as the shipowners will tell you.

There has been a reduction in the seagoing work force of 20 per cent or around 1,000 jobs. The reduced crewing is estimated currently to accrue savings in crew costs to the industry of around $50m per annum. More than 1,900 seafarers have been retrained to provide a more flexible, multi-skilled work force.

I emphasise that these reforms have been achieved in an atmosphere of industrial harmony in an industry where, only a few short years ago, employers and unions were renowned for their prolonged and bitter industrial battles. Both employers and unions are to be commended on the success of the reform program and for their support for further reform initiatives to take the industry beyond its current achievements.

In February, the Shipping Industry Reform Authority presented its report of the future directions for the industry. It recommended the development through negotiation of a further program of shipping reform to maintain the momentum of change. Currently, the Government is negotiating with the industry parties to progress that further reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. The Minister would be aware of widespread concern amongst employers about reports that the ACTU has persuaded the Government to protect it from proposed increases in penalties in relation to section 45 of the Trade Practices Act. Will the Minister assure the Senate that any increase in penalties for breaches of the Act will be applied uniformly to corporations and trade unions and that the Parliament will not be asked to arrange special deals in the courts for the Government's trade union mates?

—I am aware of speculation, but in propounding the speculation in the form of this question the honourable senator does himself no service. In the first case, I am not the Minister responsible for the Trade Practices Act. That falls within the portfolio of the Attorney-General. I know that he has that matter under consideration. In the second case—
—What is the Government's position?

—The Government's position will be revealed at an appropriate time by the Government. It is not an appropriate time now because the matter is under consideration and under review. I have discussed this matter with the Attorney-General. He has given to me some salient information that perhaps would educate this debate a little. The first point—
—What is the point?

—I am coming to it. Senator Crane should show a little patience. The point is that, of all the actions taken under section 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act against trade unions in this country, none of them have resulted in any trade union being fined. The effect of sections 45D and 45E rests on their injunctive powers and the obtaining of an injunction against action being taken. That has always succeeded in preventing that action going further. It has never meant that any of the fines under section 45 have been made or, in fact, paid.

PARA.TAB: I understand from the Attorney-General that, on that basis, he is examining sections 45D and 45E to see whether the level of fine is necessary at all. As I have said, this has never been resorted to and the injunctive power seems to be the issue that has most effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —So, it hasn't caused a problem?

—Well, in my view it has caused a problem in industrial relations. It has caused a problem because it has meant that industrial relations law has not acted on its own in affecting the outcome of industrial disputes; other law has. But that is a matter of discussion between me and the Attorney-General. At the appropriate time he, no doubt, will make a statement.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I take it from the Minister's ducking and weaving in answer to this question that penalties for breaches to the Act may not be applied uniformly to the trade union movement and to corporations. The Parliament may be asked to arrange special deals with the courts for the Government's trade union mates.

—One cannot educate a mind which is militantly committed to remaining ignorant. Senator Tierney can therefore take from that statement whatever he wishes. As I said, the Government will announce its position in due course; it is not appropriate that it does so now. My advice to Senator Tierney is: do not be too hasty; do not jump to conclusions. This Government is a government for the country. We do not do shoddy deals of the sort that Senator Tierney refers to. We make sensible law and we will announce the outcome in due course.

—I preface my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs by recognising the Government's response to the report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody which was tabled in this place yesterday and which recognised the large and disproportionate number of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who are detained in custody. Given that most of these people are now interned in institutions outside the Commonwealth Government's jurisdiction, what steps can the Commonwealth take to encourage cooperation with the States in order to bring about the reduction of the current detention rate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very encouraged to see in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald an editorial which goes a long way to answering the question raised by Senator McKiernan. The first sentence of the editorial headed `Aborigines: not just money' reads:

ANSWER.PARA: The first task arising out of the Royal Commission into Black Death in Custody is simply to keep more Aborigines out of jail.

I think that very evident point arose out of the deliberations of that royal commission. The royal commission found that Aboriginal people in custody do not die at a greater rate than non-Aboriginal people in custody. That was perhaps a surprising finding. But the royal commission did find this overwhelming difference: the rate at which Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people come into custody is about 29 times that at which the non-Aboriginal population comes into custody. If non-Aboriginal people had been imprisoned at the same rate as Aboriginal people were during the period reviewed by the royal commission, then some 8,500 deaths in custody would have resulted. That gives some idea of the magnitude of the impact on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of their detention in police cells and prisons throughout this country.

PARA.TAB: It is for that reason that we need to take urgent steps to reduce the numbers of those who are detained in such custody situations. Perhaps the real breakthrough in the Government's response in this regard is the funding of the establishment of a series of bail hostels around the country. These bail hostels will be of particular use for young Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who are often denied bail because they do not have the appropriate fixed address or the means of meeting other conditions relating to bail.

It is a fact that there is a greater likelihood of custodial sentences being imposed if young people are detained rather than granted bail. So it is very important that these bail hostels be established under the supervision of an Aboriginal person who acts as a house parent or supervisor of the bail hostel. As these hostels are established around the country, I believe that they will provide a very sensible diversion from the sorts of custody and detention which apparently lead to the rate of deaths that have been revealed by the royal commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have to be charged before they are taken into custody.

—The magistrate will divert them to the bail hostel rather than into some other form of custody. The program will also provide a framework within which the elders in the community, the house parent, the supervisor and other community members of standing will be able to take an active role in the diversion of these young Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people away from the criminal justice system in that strong custody area, which has led to such an over-representation of those peoples in custody, with the consequential deaths that have been noted.

PARA.TAB: For this to succeed there will need to be the cooperation and the understanding of the police. That is also a very important part of the Government's response. Minister Tickner emphasised yesterday that governments are not singling out police for criticism. The truth is that the police, he said, like the rest of the community, have a range of attitudes and opinions. But they can, no doubt, do much more to improve their dealings with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

There are certainly programs in place within the Australian Federal Police who are encouraging such programs to be put in place in other police forces throughout Australia so that in the contact between police and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people the understanding can be bettered. The diversion into non-custodial bail hostels can be a way of ensuring that we have a lesser representation of these people in custody and, one hopes therefore, a lesser incidence of the tragic deaths which led to the setting up of the commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Industrial Relations intend to introduce legislation to force contractors to operate within the award system?
—No.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade representing the Treasurer. Do today's balance of payment figures indicate that the Budget current account deficit estimates are still on track?

—Yes, very much so. The February current account deficit figures released today showed a fall of some $237m to $667m in seasonally adjusted terms. That would imply an annual current account balance well below the Budget forecast of a current account deficit of $14 billion in 1991-92.

PARA.TAB: The current account deficit is 34 per cent lower in the eight months to February compared with the corresponding period last year. Imports are down by 0.6 per cent. Exports are up by 9.8 per cent, which gives the lie to the constant suggestion we hear that any improvement in the trade balance is simply a function of the recession causing a reduction in imports; it is coming on the export side.

The balance of merchandise trade improved from a surplus of $77m over that period to a surplus of $2.5 billion. The figures also show that we can expect a surplus on goods and services together, the first since 1979-80. That is another vindication of the forecast in last year's Budget.

Overall, the current account deficit has fallen over the last year from 6.5 per cent of GDP to 4.3 per cent and is expected to fall to 3 3/4per cent of GDP this year, despite weak commodity prices and relatively subdued world trade growth. While there probably will be some increase in that percentage, with an increase in economic activity associated with coming out of the recession, we expect that smaller percentage to be sustainable in the longer term.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport: is it a fact that the Western Australian black spot program has not been received? Also, is it a fact that it will not be programmed until the Western Australian Government passes legislation to do with certain internal traffic laws?
—I will have to take that question on notice and get an answer from the Minister.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Has the Minister seen the document put out by the private and public hospitals associations addressing health insurance and hospital funding? Can the Minister say what the Government's response to the document is?

—I have not had time to peruse every page of that document, but I understand that the Minister for Health has. Of course he welcomes that support for the core reforms in the NHS hospital papers that is contained in those documents. But we believe that the financing proposals put forward in those documents do nothing to improve the access of Australians to health services.
—Of course they do!

—It is not as simple as saying, `Of course they do'. It is clear that what they are designed to do is to greatly improve the lot of those private hospitals, private insurance companies and, to a very much lesser extent, those public hospitals which can have private patients funded through private insurance premiums.
—And relieve the pressure on public hospitals.

—Senator Herron says that it will relieve the pressure on public hospitals, but the fact is that there is no real allowance for growth in patient numbers in these proposals. The costings say that the proposals include a reduction in Commonwealth payments to the States to leave the States in a budget neutral position. What they obviously have in mind is that the extra revenue to be generated from the bed day charges is offset by the cut in the grant to public hospitals that is envisaged under the coalition's Fightback program.Senator Herron nods in assent to that proposition.

PARA.TAB: In other words, there will actually be no more money available within the public hospital system, but there will be an offset from the private patients, with their bed day charges, only just compensating for the decline in assistance from State governments for the public hospitals, which is forced on them by the cut in funding from the Federal Government to the States as proposed by the Opposition. So there is no way in which public hospitals will be better off or able to provide more services to cater for more patients within the public hospital system. It is completely misleading to suggest that public hospitals will be improving their capacity to serve more patients in the provision of hospital care.

The fact is that the Federal Government believes that the public hospital system is the cornerstone of the Australian hospital system. It ought to be retained in a way which acknowledges the proper publicly funded support which has sustained public hospitals over many decades and which, as I say, ought to remain the real foundation for their improvement, along with other improvements required to ensure the delivery of effective health care to Australians in our hospitals.

These financing measures are simply a means of using private insurance premiums—taken out of the pockets of those who wish to use the hospital services of this country—and channelling them in a way which, as I say, barely offsets the reduction in government funding of public hospitals. Therefore, it will not improve the status of public hospitals in their ability to provide good health for Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister say from the Government's response whether this paper and its encouragement for private insurance will increase, or apply pressures to increase, health costs to the nation? What might it do to inflation?

—It is quite clear that there will be an inflationary impact of the proposals put forward as far as they rely on private health insurance premiums, because private health insurance premiums are taken into the calculation of the CPI. That is a self-evident consequence of the adoption of any such policy.
—How much will inflation go up?

—That will go up by a certain percentage, which has to be acknowledged by the Opposition, as I am sure it would be. When one considers that the Opposition will virtually require the payment of private health insurance premiums in this way by Australian households and families, in addition to the payment of their Medicare levy—which Medicare levy will only get them a 75 per cent return of the scheduled fee rather than the 85 per cent under current arrangements—one can see the co-payment which people will have to make when visiting their doctors, which is also an integral part of the Opposition's plan.

PARA.TAB: In all sorts of ways, under the Opposition proposals the cost of the provision of health care to the Australian community—whether primary health care as one visits the surgery of one's GP or the hospital system—must increase to families and households throughout Australia. In that way there is no doubt that the cost of health care throughout Australia would become much greater and would be financed simply by persons having to pay private health insurance premiums, which would then basically go into the hands of the private hospitals and, of course, the members of the AMA.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I draw the Minister's attention to Australia Post's former system of reduced mailing rates for registered publications, which enabled small trade and leisure magazines to provide their readers with attractively priced subscription rates while still making a profit. Is the Minister aware that, with the introduction of Australia Post's print post price rises, the cost of mailing these publications to subscribers will become prohibitively high? Is he also aware that these new charges will see mailing costs increase by up to 223 per cent above the level of only 18 months ago? I ask the Minister: with an inflation rate increase of just 1.5 per cent over the last year, how can Australia Post justify these new charges? I further ask the Minister: in view of the highly depressed state of Australia's economy, which has, with the flood of publications from overseas, markedly lowered advertising revenues in such publications, what action will he take to ensure that this action will not prove to be the final nail in the coffin of many small Australian publishing businesses?

—Last night this issue was raised at the Estimates Committee. Australia Post gave a number of specific answers, which I will get for Senator Bjelke-Petersen, but I think I can explain today the gist of what it said. The magazines to which the honourable senator refers have been loss-makers for Australia Post for a very long time. The losses amount to many millions of dollars; they are very considerable indeed. When we give Australia Post a charter that says, `You shall operate as a commercial organisation; you'll organise yourself on proper business lines', it is very difficult then to say to it, `But where you're making losses, you're not allowed to fix it'.

PARA.TAB: The truth is, of course, that the ordinary users of postal services have been subsidising the rates for these magazines for many years. Whether that cross-subsidy can be justified is, I think, the heart of the problem. As I understand last night's evidence, the average increases are around 30 to 35 per cent, and they were necessary to get this service up to the point, at least, of being commercially viable. I do not believe that the Government ought to sanction the kind of cross-subsidy that makes every person who uses the postal service across Australia subsidise the loss-making parts of the business. So I think really what Australia Post has done is live up to the charter. I do not really think we can ask it to do any more than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is in three parts, is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Firstly, can the Minister confirm that the final report of the Resource Assessment Commission Forest and Timber Inquiry has been forwarded to the Prime Minister and other relevant Ministers for their consideration; secondly, if so, why has the Government failed to make this important report available to the Parliament, particularly as its recommendations would be central to consideration by the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs of the Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1992; and, thirdly, will the Minister undertake immediately to make this report available to the Parliament?
—My understanding is that the report will be tabled tomorrow, and I think that will in effect answer the other questions that the honourable senator has put to us.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. The Minister will recall that on 25 March, in response to a question without notice from Senator Childs, Senator Button said that an additional $51m was being made available by the Prime Minister's One Nation statement to assist with the restructuring of the textile, clothing and footwear industries. Would the Minister comment on the statement by the President of the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Council of Australia that the amount now allocated to the restructuring program is in fact not $51m but only $10m more than had been originally promised for this purpose and as outlined on 12 March 1991 in the statement, `Building a Competitive Australia'.

—I have not seen the statement referred to by the industry spokesman that Senator Archer mentioned. I am aware of what the One Nation statement said. I am aware too that, in terms of tariff protection for this industry, his Party favours a package which removes all tariff protection—a zero tariff protection—which would bleed this industry and drive it into the ground. But in terms of this statement by the industry in relation to what Senator Button said on 24 March, I will obtain the necessary information and reply to the honourable senator's question later.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Given that the States are predictably saying that they do not have enough money to implement the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, and given that this opportunity is generally acknowledged as the last opportunity this century to move forward on the question of Aboriginal affairs, I ask the Minister: does he believe that the States, as they are claiming, do not have enough money for this purpose? Does the Government support the call by the New South Wales Premier for the matter to be addressed at the Premiers Conference next month? Finally, if the matter is not resolved adequately, is there a case for the Commonwealth to assume its national responsibility in the delivery of services to Aboriginal people?

—In an earlier question relating specifically to the law and justice response in this package, Senator Tate commended this morning's editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald, as I wish to do. The opening paragraph of that editorial echoed precisely what the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs said when he brought this statement down in the House of Representatives yesterday, and that is that the fundamental aim of any package that is designed to attempt to adequately respond to Aboriginal deaths in custody must be directed at keeping Aboriginal people out of gaol.

PARA.TAB: The editorial went on to say that since the report was brought down, 25 Aboriginal people have died in custody. In fact, the precise figure is 28. It may be of some interest to honourable senators to know that in that same period, 150 non-Aboriginal people died in custody. The other pertinent thing about that statistic is that those figures are consistent across the age groups. For every one Aboriginal person in the 20- to 30-age range who has died in custody, about six non-Aboriginal people in the same age group have died in custody.

The impact of that figure of course is that it precisely reflects, as Senator Tate alluded to in his answer, the early research of the Aboriginal Deaths in Custody Commission which found, some three years ago when this process started, that that was the situation. Therefore, a fair test is whether the Government's response addresses that fundamental question of attempting to reduce the numbers of Aboriginal people in prison.
Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes indeed, I agree with that. I think that the statement comprehensively passes that test. In terms of the response, it is fair to say that it was always expected, by every party concerned in this, that there would be a national response to what is a serious national problem; that is, a combined effort by Federal, State and Territory governments. Of course, many of the specific problems relating to the difficulties Aboriginal people are having emanate directly—I do not say this in a critical sense; I simply say it as a matter of fact—from areas that are fundamentally the responsibility of State governments. Therefore it is appropriate for the Commonwealth to look to the States to assist in providing an adequate response.

PARA.TAB: I am not in a position to answer whether the States have enough money to fund this. Everyone always cries poor, but I am not in a position to comment on the budgets of all the States and Territories. I noted the suggestion of Premier Greiner. I also noted the public statements of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs that he is confident that he can advance this matter satisfactorily. We all hope that he does so by further consultations with State governments, and I understand that he will embark on that process.

In terms of the Commonwealth's fundamental responsibilities, I believe that the Commonwealth's initial response has set the lead, as it is designed to do. It is a substantial response; it is a package of $150m. In particular, I wish to applaud the direction of money into bail hostels as part of that package. That is a practical, sensible and productive response to what is a real problem on the ground in terms of trying to keep young Aboriginal offenders, in particular, out of gaol in the first instance. I am also very pleased to see that a very substantial sum of money out of that package will be directed towards alleviating substance abuse. Regrettably—and it is too consistent to pretend otherwise—substance abuse is a recurring and consistent feature in Aboriginal offences.

The Commonwealth has given a substantial and commendable upfront lead to the States in what has been a very substantial initial response by the Commonwealth. I am confident—as is the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs—that the matter can be progressed satisfactorily through negotiation with the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I preface my question by noting that last night the Cabinet decided there should no longer be any opportunity for incidental tobacco advertising on television on the basis that the Government accepts a link between certain television programming and subsequent behaviour. As the Minister intends to permit sexual deviates, armed with a PIN number and a Smartcard, to perv on pay TV pornography in the comfort of their own homes, can the Minister explain why the rights of these men should take priority over the rights of all women not to be degraded or exposed to physical danger from copycat sex crimes?

—It takes a fair bit to surprise me in this place, but that question has surprised me. I preface my answer by saying that I can only tell Senator Newman what I intend to recommend to the Government—because obviously no decision has been made, so it is not Government policy—that I do not intend to allow pornography on pay TV. I made that fairly clear at a meeting of Party colleagues the other night and I can repeat it here. At least, that is what I will recommend. Whether my colleagues seek to overrule me is another question. Certainly, we will not accept pornography on pay television.

PARA.TAB: Senator Harradine interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The next question concerns R rating. If Senator Newman, or indeed Senator Harradine in his interjection, are implying that an R rating equals an X rating and that the content is the same, they would both be wrong. The X-rated stuff is very much tougher. As far as pay television is concerned—and, again, this is a personal opinion and not Government policy—
—You're wrong.
—Senator Harradine should listen to what I am saying.
—Order! Ignore the interjection, Senator Richardson.
—We have a fundamental disagreement on that point, but that is not too surprising.

PARA.TAB: Senator Harradine interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a matter of what I have seen with my own eyes. Whether our eyes can mislead us is another matter. The eyes were popping out a couple of times on this trip! People can get R-rated movies from videos stores or watch them in a movie house, and when they are paying extra money, when it is not free to air television, when it requires a dish on the roof and an extra box on the television set, they will be entitled to see R-rated movies.

PARA.TAB: Senator Harradine interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a minute, Senator Harradine. Let me answer. If you want to ask another question, I will be happy to answer it. I believe that the system can only work properly with the right kind of smart card technology. That technology is in operation in a number of countries. It means that parents will be able to determine in the home themselves what they believe is suitable for their children to view. The whole pay TV operation will not work unless the card is in. It will be up to parents to determine whether or not kids can see programs. If the argument is to be that adults cannot watch on pay TV—something they will be paying about $40 a month for—the same film that they can see at the movie house or get for $4 or $5 at the video store, then I am afraid I have to disagree with Senator Newman.
—Is the Minister for Shipping and Aviation aware of ongoing attacks on the supposed Federal funding for the upgrading of the Townsville port? Will this criticism alter Government plans for this port?
—A question without notice, Mr President. Yes, I am aware of the ongoing attacks on the funding of the Townsville port, although they have receded in recent weeks.
—What about Senator Macdonald? Is he still involved in the port?

—Yes, indeed. I was extremely interested to see that, on the same day that the attack was launched in the Parliament by Senator Parer, the Opposition in the Senate announced by way of a press release that it was about to—I use its words—blitz north Queensland with a team of 19 Opposition senators. Indeed they did blitz. Senator Macdonald put out a supporting press release saying that it was not going to be a fun tourist arrangement, that it was going to be all `go, go, go'. I religiously searched all of the media statements covering the trip and I could not find out where they went, went, went. The only prominent press coverage of the `go, go, go' trip was a very prominent photograph in the Townsville Bulletin of five of the go, go, goers whitewater-rafting down a river.

PARA.TAB: The thing that I most noted, because I waited for it, was that the team of five peeled off to Townsville and spent one day there. Despite the fact that the Federal Opposition here in the Senate specifically attacked and criticised the funding of the port of Townsville—the most important port in north Queensland and one of the economic heartbeats of that city—not one single senator bothered to go near the port while the senators were in Townsville. Not one of them went near the Port Authority. Not one of them lifted a finger to actually investigate what the money was likely to be spent on or to give the Port Authority an opportunity to put its views.

I believe, therefore, that the real reason for the trip to Queensland was exactly what the honourable member for Herbert said it was—a task force to try to find more things to knock off the Federal Budget for the Fightback package.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr President. If Senator Collins wants to debate the trip, we are more than happy to do that and to refer him to what the Townsville Bulletin editorial said about the trip when it congratulated the Liberal Party for showing some interest in north Queensland, which the Labor Party never does. If he wants to do that—
—Order! The honourable senator will resume his seat. There is no point of order.
—My question is—
—Who fell off the raft?
—I was not on the raft, Senator Burns.

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections on the Government side.

—Is the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs aware that the Australian Government's record in relation to the privacy of our citizens has received strong criticism at the inaugural meeting of the worldwide privacy body, Privacy International, which was held in Washington this month? Can the Minister confirm or deny that the Government is to establish a major investigative database on Australian citizens, which is to be known as the law enforcement access network? If such a network is to be established, can the Minister indicate to the Senate what public consultation has taken place, what is the intended usage of the database and whether the Privacy Commissioner is to be given the right to overview the operation of the database itself? Finally, can the Minister give an undertaking that there will be a full and honest revelation from the Government of the full facts surrounding any database of Australian citizens?

The air traffic controller asks the pilot to set one of three or four frequencies on the transponder in squawk ident and that gives an indication on the blip, on the radar screen, as to what the particular aircraft is. PARA.TAB: What happened on this occasion and on other occasions was that no indication of the presence of the aircraft appeared on the radar screens, according to the air traffic controllers. That is documented and beyond dispute. It is not correct to blame the failure on the transponder in the way that Senator Collins did. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
recalls the long suffering of the Cambodian people,
notes the remarkable diplomatic achievement enshrined in the Agreements on the Comprehensive Political Settlement of the Cambodia Conflict signed in Paris on 23 October 1991,
recognises the difficult task ahead of the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia (UNTAC),
affirms Australia's commitment to assist the Cambodian people to take control again of their own affairs and return to peaceful and productive lives,
affirms Australia's support for the United Nations in its new and enhanced role in promoting world peace and solving long-standing regional conflicts,
affirms its support for Australia's positive response to the request made by the UN Secretary General for support in implementing the Cambodian peace accords,
expresses its full confidence in, and support for, Australian Defence Force men and women deployed for peacekeeping in Cambodia and looks forward to their safe return, and
congratulates Lieutenant-General Sanderson on his appointment as UNTAC military commander and wishes him well in his assignment.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to incorporate my statement in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President
It is appropriate that the Senate focus today on the subject of Cambodia, and on the prospects for a lasting peace in that long-suffering country.
Great crimes have been committed against the Cambodian people. The tragedy of the conflict has been brought home to us all through the personal witness of many Cambodian Australians.

On 28 February, the United Nations Security Council passed a resolution formally creating the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia or UNTAC, the body responsible for implementation of the historic Comprehensive Political Settlement of the Cambodia Conflict.
In response to the UN Secretary General's request for contributions to UNTAC's operations, Australia has agreed to provide 495 Defence Force personnel to form the Force Communications Unit.
This total includes 65 communicators already deployed as part of the UN Advance Mission in Cambodia.
If conditions are right in Cambodia, the Government expects that the main Australian contingent will begin deploying during this month.
They will be joined in the field by 40 signallers from the New Zealand Defence Force.

Furthermore, Australia has provided UNTAC's military commander, Lieutenant-General John Sanderson, who commenced duty in Cambodia on 15 March. Australia will contribute six staff to his headquarters unit.
The Government also expects to contribute to UNTAC's civilian component, whose composition is still under consideration by the United Nations.
As part of this, we have decided to provide ten police officers.
In addition, Mr Michael Maley, an officer of the Australian Electoral Commission, has taken up duty in Phnom Penh as Deputy Electoral Commissioner for UNTAC.
Mr President
The creation of UNTAC is the culmination of years of complex and difficult negotiation.
The peace plan embodied in the remarkable agreements signed in Paris on 23 October 1991 provides a way of ending the nightmare of Cambodia's recent past.
The main objectives of the settlement are to end the civil war, and to allow the Cambodian people to choose a new government through genuinely free and fair elections.
Reflecting the complexity of the Cambodian conflict, the Paris agreements provide for an unprecedented and ambitious role for the United Nations in the implementation of the peace plan.
UNTAC will have a peacekeeping role supervising, monitoring and verifying the cease-fire, partial demobilisation of armed forces, and the cessation of external military assistance.
UNTAC most definitely will not have a role enforcing or imposing the peace if hostilities break out.

In the civilian sphere, not only will UNTAC have a role in organising and conducting the elections, it will also play a role in monitoring and supervising the interim administration of the country to ensure a neutral political environment for the elections.
In addition, the United Nations will be responsible for coordinating and assisting the repatriation and resettlement of some hundreds of thousands of Cambodian refugees and displaced persons.
Mr President
The Cambodia peace settlement is a striking demonstration of the fundamental changes that have occurred in the international system.

Unprecedented cooperation between the Permanent Five members of the Security Council has greatly enhanced the scope for resolving regional conflicts. The UN system has been able to harness broad-based support for its peacekeeping role.

The subtle and dynamic balance of interests in the Cambodia peace agreements reflects the close involvement and cooperation of the Permanent Five members of the Security Council in the negotiating process.
The efforts of the Indonesian and French governments deserve special mention. Their initiative, courage and persistence were essential to the success of the peace plan.

Great credit must also go, of course, to the Cambodians themselves. Those of us who have not known their suffering, or seen the evil they have seen, can only wonder what human qualities it takes to sit down and talk about the future, about peace, and about national reconciliation.
Mr President
Australia played a significant role in the long process leading up to the Paris agreements.
In the mid 1980s, former Foreign Minister Hayden was active in regional diplomacy which sought to identify a basis for dialogue between the parties to the Cambodian conflict.

In late 1989, Senator Evans played a key role in breaking the impasse following the first Paris Conference on Cambodia in July and August 1989. The core of Senator Evans's proposal, which was taken up by the Permanent Five members of the Security Council, was an enhanced role for the United Nations in the transitional period preceding elections in Cambodia.
Senator Evans's resourceful and energetic pursuit of peace in Cambodia has earned him nomination for the Nobel Peace Prize. It has also earned international respect for Australia.
Mr President
In moving this resolution today I pay regard to the achievement of Senator Evans and his Department.

In light of our diplomatic contribution, it was appropriate that Australia was the first country to establish accreditation to the Supreme National Council, the interim body in which Cambodian sovereignty has been vested during the transitional period.
Australia was also among the first to supply troops to carry out the vital task of establishing communications and infrastructure in preparation for the deployment of the main UNTAC force.
It is appropriate that we now help to see the process through.
The return of Australian soldiers to Indo-China in the cause of peace is a matter for us to reflect on with justifiable pride.
With peace secured in Cambodia, we shall be able to welcome the countries of Indo-China back into the mainstream of regional activity.
We can confidently expect them to become part of the dynamism of Asia.
Vietnam will now be able to emerge from its isolation and, with Cambodia, play its part in regional and international affairs.
In parallel with the improved prospects for peace in Cambodia, Australia will resume direct bilateral aid.

The Minister for Trade and Overseas Development announced today that, over the next four years, Australia will provide approximately 49 million Australian dollars in development assistance to Cambodia. This total includes 23 million dollars for new bilateral aid.
In addition, during this financial year, we are providing approximately 7.7 million Australian dollars in disaster relief and assistance to displaced Cambodians.
Mr President
Aspects of the comprehensive settlement have been criticised by some observers.
It is suggested that it would somehow have been better to exclude the Khmer Rouge from the peace process because of their responsibility for the atrocities committed by the former Pol Pot regime.

Involvement of the Khmer Rouge in the process does not reflect a judgment by the Australian or other governments that the Khmer Rouge can now be trusted. Rather, it reflects a realistic assessment that the only available effective way of containing the military threat they pose, and of ending the civil war, was to involve them and their main backers—China—as parties to the agreement.
Put simply, a peace settlement without the Khmer Rouge and China would not be a peace settlement at all.
It has also been suggested that the settlement could have been improved by providing for 100 per cent rather than for at least 70 per cent demobilisation of the armed forces of the Cambodian parties.
Obviously such a provision would have been preferable, but the outcome set out in the Paris agreements is the best that could be negotiated.

It is the judgment of the United States, Russia, China, France, Britain, all significant Asian states and Australia that the Paris settlement represents the best available, realistic basis for a just and durable peace in Cambodia.
Mr President
UNTAC will be the costliest, as well as the most comprehensive peacekeeping operation yet undertaken by the United Nations.

It is expected to involve approximately 15,900 military personnel, 3,600 civilian police and 3,300 civilian administrators. More than 50 countries have been requested to contribute to this complex undertaking.
The initial UN estimate of the cost for a duration of 18 months is 1.9 billion US dollars. Australia's share of assessed contributions for this amount is 1.51 per cent or 28.7 million US dollars.

I should also advise the Senate that Cabinet agreed in October 1991 to provide supplementation to the Defence Budget of 49 million Australian dollars to fund the estimated costs involved in making our contribution to UNTAC and the United Nations Advance Mission in Cambodia. This is separate from our assessed contribution to UNTAC's budget, described above. We expect this will eventually be partially offset by reimbursements from the UN of some 19.7 million Australian dollars, but this will take some time to materialise.
The final UNTAC plan and budget are now being scrutinised in New York by representatives of major donors including Australia. It will be some weeks before the final budget is approved.

Along with other donors, Australia hopes that, as implementation of the settlement proceeds, an increasing habit of cooperation among the Cambodian parties will allow savings in UNTAC personnel and costs.
Mr President
Generally speaking, the settlement is working.

In the five months since it was signed, the remarkable thing has been not the number of violations or the number of disputes, but the way in which the Paris agreements have held firm, and the way in which the parties have repeatedly reaffirmed their commitment to the settlement in all its detail.

Of course, there have been incidents which threaten the whole process, and the Government has viewed with particular concern the recent fighting in Kompong Thom province. But we must look beyond these hurdles without in any sense trivialising them.
Implementation of the peace plan may well prove more difficult than its negotiation.
There are bound to be further setbacks.
We should expect them and not be disheartened when they occur.
The Government's decision to commit Australian forces to the Cambodian peacekeeping operation was not taken lightly.
The UN forces will face risks from mines, from disease, from banditry, and possibly from fresh outbreaks of fighting.
The Government has assessed these risks and has weighed them carefully. It does not underestimate them, or the need to take every prudent precaution to protect our troops.
We have made this commitment, however, because the opportunity to help restore peace to Cambodia is one which the international community cannot lightly let go.
The UN commitment to help Cambodia also serves Australia's direct interests, and those of our neighbours, by helping to create a more peaceful and prosperous region.
But it is important to emphasise again that Australian forces will not be participating in the UN operation in order to enforce or impose the peace in Cambodia.
That is a task beyond the UN mandate.
Rather, the Australian forces will be in Cambodia to help keep a peace on which the Cambodian parties themselves have agreed.
That is the condition under which UNTAC is being deployed. It is the whole basis of the Paris peace accords. It is the condition under which Australian troops have been offered to the United Nations.
If we conclude that there is no longer a peace to keep in Cambodia, the Australian and other UN forces will have to be withdrawn.

But we do not expect that to happen. All sides in the conflict have invested so much effort in the peace process, and the Cambodian people have so much to gain from its success, that we think the prospects for a successful outcome remain promising.
If we turn our backs on this opportunity to help consolidate the hard work of the peace-makers, we shall be sentencing the Cambodian people to further years of cruelty and suffering.
Mr President
As I already mentioned, UNTAC's primary military functions will be supervising and verifying the cease-fire, partial demobilisation of armed forces, and the cessation of external military assistance.
UNTAC will also assist in the clearance of hundreds of thousands of mines.
Australia's contingent will provide the crucial communications network for the UNTAC military operation.
Our service men and women will be operating in a difficult and sometimes dangerous environment.
Already Lieutenant-Colonel Russell Stuart has been wounded in the course of his duty with the UN Advance Mission in Cambodia. That incident underlines the risks which the peacekeeping personnel face.

But Australians can be proud of the skill and professionalism which Australian Defence Force units have brought to UN peacekeeping and other operations around the world—from the Sinai, Iraq and the Red Sea, to the Western Sahara and the Afghan border.
Their reputation is reflected in the UN Secretary-General's decision to appoint Lieutenant-General Sanderson commander of UNTAC's military force.
I am sure all members of this Senate will join me in extending congratulations to General Sanderson on his appointment and in wishing him well in his assignment.
I am equally sure members will want to express their confidence in and support for the Australian Defence Force men and women deployed in Cambodia.
There is no more honourable duty than the one they will go to perform—to preserve the peace.
We know they will serve Australia and the cause of peace with distinction, and we look forward to their safe return.
Mr President, we hope that return will not be long delayed.
The aim of the United Nations presence in Cambodia is not to oversee developments there indefinitely but to manage a transition from war to peace, from factional distrust to national reconciliation.
May 1993 has been set as the target date for the UN-organised elections. The UN Secretary-General intends withdrawing UNTAC about six months after that date.
I know it is the earnest desire of all members of this Senate that the Cambodian people will seize this opportunity to establish a just and lasting peace in their country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to the motion that has been moved to take note of the statement and, in particular, the terms of the motion that have been put by the Government before the chamber this afternoon. This, obviously, is an important debate on a most serious matter—that of not only the Government's assessment of the situation in Cambodia, but also its decision to increase Australian forces in Cambodia to a number of about 500. We are pleased that the Government has finally brought a statement to the Parliament on this issue. This is something that we have been seeking of the Government for some five months.

PARA.TAB: As much as anybody, we want to see peace for the Cambodian people. They have suffered enormously under the Khmer Rouge policy of genocide. I remind you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that during that horrible period more than a million Cambodians were killed; or in other terms, over a quarter of the total population. Since then they have continued to suffer during the civil war. Some 350,000 have been driven out of their homes and their country and now live in the camps along the Thai border. According to the UNHCR, at least another 150,000 can be fairly described as internal refugees who have been forced to leave their homes and are temporarily living elsewhere within Cambodia. These people have lived for too long in misery and in an environment of terror.

In government and in opposition we have constantly looked for ways to support the Cambodian people. We have supported the UNBRO, the border relief organisation of the UN, and the work it has done on the border in the camps. We have helped in all possible ways to support the Cambodian people through support for the Red Cross, UNHCR and NGOs. We have also sought to try to find ways to help them find a peace. Obviously, our preferred solution was to support the two non-communist Khmer factions. That was because we believe that the Cambodians not only deserve peace, but also freedom.

In more recent years we saw more potential as the Hun Sen regime at least somewhat liberalised and clearly offered a preferable alternative to the Khmer Rouge. It was offering at least some order and stability, notwithstanding its communist ideology. We looked at the possibility of its perhaps joining with the two non-communist Khmer factions in some peaceful solution. We always had difficulties with any settlement proposals that would again inflict the Khmer Rouge upon the Cambodian people. As the Senate would be aware, we advocated that the international community prosecute Pol Pot and the other leaders of that genocidal regime for genocide in the International Court of Justice. For some years we invited the Australian Government to take a leadership role in that project, which invitation was not taken up. We saw advantage in excluding the Khmer Rouge, giving it no international legitimacy at all.

We recognise the difficulties inherent in our preferred solution, namely, the strength of the Khmer Rouge military within Cambodia, the determination of its principal backer, China, that it not be deserted and, when it came to the crunch on several occasions, the unwillingness of the Sihanouk faction to isolate the Khmer Rouge, thus end the resistance coalition and potentially become the target of a more powerful adversary. But the down side of the alternative, any quadripartite solution—a solution that incorporated the Khmer Rouge—was to embrace that horrible regime and to accept its good faith. It is not surprising that the Hun Sen Government in Phnom Penh would not accept that solution either.

Thus over a period of some time, the international community sought to develop an option. We give credit to Senator Evans and the Australian Government for providing commitment and effort in seeking a solution other than simply a quadripartite solution that would not be accepted. That alternative option, or the development of the quadripartite option, was to provide and enhance the United Nations role, which would give some support to the Khmer factions if they were in fact able to reach peace.

Hun Sen was to have some security guarantee in the form of a large United Nations peacekeeping force. The Khmer Rouge was given a benefit under this scheme. It would have the guarantee of not sacrificing its military advantage in a peace. That would be given by the United Nations assuming principal functions or at least supervisory functions of the Cambodian Government, and would be given a place within the Supreme National Council to be established in the run-up to free and fair elections.

So the Khmer Rouge was dealt with by the international community with Australia playing a lead role. I regret to say that we saw the unedifying spectacle of the former Khmer Rouge Interior Minister, who ran the torture chambers in the country, receiving international endorsement and a seat on the SNC. It is no wonder that we found that an unappealing prospect. We have seen develop a settlement proposal that, despite a United Nations presence, really requires the goodwill of the Khmer Rouge to succeed. On that basis it is no wonder that we have remained sceptical. Nevertheless we have acknowledged that it could work. The Khmer factions signed on the bottom line. The international community said it would support it. Obviously, despite our reservations, we said, in principle, that we would support it also because, as I said at the outset, the Cambodians deserve every chance at peace.

Senator Evans often quotes me, saying that I did not believe the comprehensive settlement would work. That was a comment I made in Cambodia some 18 months or so ago when I was doing my bit to seek to persuade the Hun Sen Government in Phnom Penh to join with the two non-communist factions in free and fair elections that would thus exclude the Khmer Rouge. What I argued, of course, was that if Hun Sen was prepared to show that initiative, which regrettably in the end he was not, he would engage and attract enormous international support. But it did not go in that direction, as I said, because although he spoke of holding an election, he was not prepared at that time to hold a democratic election. What I said then still remains, to the extent that a comprehensive settlement is not just a signed document and evidence of international support.

A comprehensive settlement is a peace and stability in which Cambodians can fairly determine their destiny. That has yet to be achieved. The issue, then, is whether the path that has been chosen, which Australia is supporting by sending military forces, will achieve that objective. Look at that for a moment. We see continued fighting on the ground, principally by the Khmer Rouge, fighting that has been described in recent weeks as the most intense in the past year. We see a campaign of terror being conducted by the Khmer Rouge using its traditional methodology, in this instance, of firing artillery rounds indiscriminately into villages. We see the Khmer Rouge intimidating refugees on the border, refugees which the UN, with our support, is seeking to relocate back into Cambodia. We see a settlement that has not excluded Pol Pot and his deputies from continuing their power and control over the Khmer Rouge forces.

When we say that, Senator Evans simply accuses us of carping. To work, the UN plan must be realistic. Apart from our concern that the Khmer Rouge is not participating and will not genuinely participate in the peace process, the timetable for repatriation of refugees is simply impossible.

The wet comes in about two months and lasts until about October. Three hundred and fifty thousand refugees were to be resettled before the end of the year. This week the United Nations is moving the first 600 refugees. It is supposed to increase to 10,000 a week, which is obviously impossible. That impossibility is already being acknowledged by this somewhat quaint notion of moving the refugees from the camps in Thailand to new camps just across the border in Cambodia where they will be able to vote in the election that is planned as part of the process.

Additionally, the process of cantonment and disarming in this environment is highly doubtful. We will be amazed if the Khmer Rouge, in practice, lays down 70 per cent of its arms and disbands 70 per cent of its forces. Even Senator Evans last night acknowledged that it has at least two to three years of arms hidden away. It has wealth from the gem mines, and the region, as we know, is sadly already flooded with weapons. But even under the Paris Agreement it is still not a complete disarming. Although Senator Evans criticised us for arguing the other day that there should be an effort to increase the disarming to a full 100 per cent, subsequent to his statement the Security Council has included it within its resolution as the desired option—or, more than desired; something that should be aimed at. That is not surprising. Even under this scheme, if 30 per cent of the 200,000 regular forces still in Cambodia and the 250,000 irregular forces maintain their arms and their combat readiness, they create a most uncomfortable environment.

Furthermore, we see little prospect of Hun Sen, particularly that he has now reached a more comfortable relationship with Prince Sihanouk, passing to the UN the supervisory functions of government; that is, the five key portfolios of foreign affairs, defence, communications, interior and one other, which is the plan that we are seeking to put into effect. It is interesting that not so many months ago, when Hun Sen was in this country, he said to us in response to questions that he had no intention of passing over those functions or giving up those functions.

So in this environment is it a reality to see a free and fair election next May? We doubt that it is so. We are concerned also that, despite the rhetoric of the international community, there has been very little forthcoming. The process of establishing UNTAC has been incredibly slow. Australia and some others, notably France and Indonesia, have kept the process going by developing the notion of a phased deployment, hopefully locking in the international community. But from what we learnt last night, only $35m of the initial $200m has been committed. So $35m of the total estimated cost of $1.9 billion has been committed.

Of the 40-odd countries that have made a commitment for an initial force, we understand from Senator Evans last night that it is a force of only 4,000. But the Indonesians have provided an infantry battalion of about 800, the Malaysians a similar number and, under this statement, Australia will be providing 500. Adding those together, Madam Acting Deputy President, you will realise that the others will not be providing many at all.

That initial 4,000 is out of the projected force, the documented intended force, of some 15,000. Bearing in mind that this was to be an 18-month project due to end about the middle of next year, we do not see in these figures great determination on the part of the international community. Australia is clearly a driving force in this commitment. We commend the leadership aspect that Australia has been prepared to show, but the question is whether the process is realistic. We are still concerned about the lack of information that is put before us even in relation to the Australian force.

We are told that we will be sending 500 military communicators, but we are not told specifically what they will do. Last night, Senator Evans said that they would build some form of Cambodian Telecom. We should have been told, I would suggest, in this statement exactly what will be their functions and where they will be deployed. Presumably, they will be attached to the infantry—in the first instance to the Malaysian and Indonesian battalions—but we were not told that. As I said last night, it seems strange to me to have some 500 communicators for 1,600 troops.

We were told in this statement for the first time that we will be sending 10 police officers, but we are not told what their functions will be. We are not told what countries have committed forces and the nature of the forces that they have committed. We are not told specifically for how long the Australians will be deployed. If we are right, and the UN time assessments are unrealistic, it is likely that Australian forces will be locked in for a long time.

We are given in this statement no frank assessment on the issue of the ongoing fighting and conditions on the ground. That, we would have thought, would be the bare minimum that we could reasonably expect in this statement and that the Australian people could expect.

Last week, Senator Evans was dismissing the fighting that is occurring as simply skirmishes by war lords, but that does not seem to be the word that is coming out of Cambodia. Yet this statement says, for the first time, that the Australian deployment will be only if conditions are right. Does that imply that conditions are not right at present? Is Senator Evans saying that this situation of skirmishing war lords who happen to be using heavy artillery and firing indiscriminately into villages and destroying bridges and roads, are conditions when it is not right to send the force? We do not understand why this was not explicitly dealt with in this statement that is before us today.

We are given no details as to how the UN proposes to assume supervision of the functions of government in Cambodia that I mentioned a few moments ago. There is no analysis of the effect upon the process of the breakdown of the SNC procedure. I understand that the SNC in its full composition has only been able to meet once. I think it has tried to meet on six occasions but it has not been able to completely meet for various reasons. Yet this was a critical component of the total package. What is the effect of that breakdown upon the package and the peace process as a whole?

We are given no details of what role, if any, Australia will play in the demobilisation process. We are disappointed that there is no support in this document for the UN Security Council proposition of 100 per cent demobilisation, which I mentioned also a few moments ago.

Regrettably, the statement does not tell the Australian people much at all about this major commitment. It is a major commitment not only in terms of the forces that we are sending and the leadership role that we are assuming but also in terms of the cost. We are told of $49m which will be required from the Defence vote and about $35m in Australian dollar terms which will be our compulsory contribution to UNTAC; $7.7m in disaster relief and the increased aid vote. So a very large sum of Australian taxpayers' dollars is being committed.

I might say in passing that we certainly offer our support to the bilateral aid vote. I want to take this opportunity to commend the incredible work that the NGOs have done in Cambodia over the last 10 years or so when a bilateral program was not in place. I have had the opportunity to visit them and learn from them first-hand of their work. They clearly deserve our commendation and gratitude.

TALK.START.PARA: —How are you going to pay for that?

—If Senator Evans reads the paper, he will see that we have said that we will give priority to our region in aid, which is more than the Government is prepared to do. The Australian Government has not kept the public adequately informed as to the major commitment it is making. It should have put down a statement in this Parliament at the time it assigned the first 50-odd communicators to Cambodia. As I said at the outset, we have had to wait some five months for this promised statement and we still do not have as much detail as is desirable.

PARA.TAB: The Government has sought to take us for granted and expected a blanket endorsement in the same way that it has taken the wider Australian community for granted. We hope that it will now keep the Parliament better informed and we believe that we have a right to expect that. In the event of any significant changes in the size of our force, in the cost, the mission goals, security assessments, timetable or other important details, we expect, and I believe reasonably expect, the Government to inform the Parliament. And we reserve the right to address such changes that might be made by the Government from time to time.

Nevertheless, despite our concerns and our reservations, which I believe are fairly put on the record, we will not let Australian forces go off without bipartisan support. We will not do what Labor once did. We know that the forces will perform in a way which will be of great credit to Australia, as they have in other peacekeeping missions in the past.

We congratulate General Sanderson on his appointment as military commander. We are pleased that the Government has finally stressed that our forces will not have an enforcement function. We have always said that the international community cannot make peace for the Khmer factions. We hope that the process will work. As I said at the outset, too many Cambodians have suffered for too long. We therefore will support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are pleased to support this motion endorsing Australia's contribution to the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia. Our endorsement comes without qualification, despite our full recognition that there are dangers which will be encountered by Australian personnel in Cambodia and that the successful completion by UNTAC of its mission cannot be guaranteed.

PARA.TAB: This is an unusual occasion. We have several differences with the Government and the Opposition on matters of foreign policy—the Gulf War and self-determination for East Timor spring to mind—but this is not one of them. The Government's policy on Cambodia is one which we have come to fully support, notwithstanding some earlier reservations about the inclusion of the Khmer Rouge in the peace process. It is clear to us that the peace process, while necessarily an imperfect creature of compromise, gives real hope that the protracted and unparalleled suffering of the Cambodian people can be brought to an end in the foreseeable future.

By contrast, until today's support for this motion by the Opposition, which we congratulate it on, the Democrats have been disappointed by the stance taken by the Opposition. This is not to suggest that the concerns raised by Senator Hill are not valid, but rather that undue weight has been given to them. The unfortunate tone in which they have been raised created the strong impression that the Opposition had little enthusiasm for the United Nation's unprecedented efforts to achieve peace in Cambodia. There was a striking contrast between the Opposition's reluctant attitude towards this operation and its wholehearted enthusiasm for the Gulf war.

The Democrats regard the UN's work in Cambodia as a very large step towards a just and peaceful new world order. However, it must be said that it is a step which has been taken many years later than it should have been. The lack of interest by the world in general to mediate a just peace in Indo-China from the 1950s until the 1980s has seen that region torn apart by the Vietnam war, the resultant destabilisation of Cambodia and the rise to power of the Khmer Rouge, led by Pol Pot, in 1975. Throughout the reign of that despicable tyrant, the UN and the world continued to take no action, although Vietnam was punished when, in 1979, it invaded Cambodia and ended the four years of terror which left one million people dead, perhaps more.

It would be wrong to suggest that Vietnam's invasion was driven by an altruistic commitment to human rights; it most certainly was not. But the fact remains that it brought to a halt a campaign of genocide which matched any of the blackest periods in world history in its horror and brutality. It is to the eternal shame of the wider international community that we all failed to help the Cambodian people when their plight became clear. Finally, in 1992, we are seeing belated but, this time, concerted action.

It is worth recalling that past members of the Australian Parliament readily supported the Vietnam war, during which the United States bombed Cambodia, precipitating instability and a power vacuum which was filled by Pol Pot. I expect all Australians to feel some sense of historical moral responsibility to help right the wrongs done to the Cambodian people. Indeed, it is profoundly ironic that not much more than a year ago most members of this Parliament were straining at the leash to send Australian troops to the Gulf war. Surely the Cambodian situation vitally engages Australia's interests at least as much as Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Peace in Cambodia and an end to Vietnam's isolation hold the promise of democracy, improved human rights and economic development in a large part of our own region.

Both the Government and the Opposition justified Australia's support for the Gulf war on the grounds that support for a strong United Nations was in our international interests; it is, but the Gulf war was not a UN controlled operation, while this Cambodian peace process actually is.

The work of UNTAC is a real contribution to a new world order. It is an attempt to achieve justice and peace without the force of arms. It aims to protect the human rights of all affected parties, not just a select group. It seeks to establish a functioning system of democracy.

We can all take great pride in the important role which Australians will play in the work of UNTAC. The 65 communicators now in Cambodia and the 430 defence personnel, 10 police officers and other civilians who will follow are to be congratulated for their vital contribution to an important step forward in the conduct of world affairs. In particular, we congratulate Lieutenant-General Sanderson on his appointment as UNTAC military commander, and Mr Michael Maley as UNTAC's deputy electoral commissioner. We offer our best wishes to them and to their families, for we all know that the families suffer just as much as those who are out in the field in these situations. We strongly endorse the part of this motion which looks forward to their safe return.

As I have already said, while the Democrats regard UNTAC as having a good chance of succeeding, we are not blind to the dangers and the possibility of failure, and we never have been. This is due in no small measure to the realistic and rational assessments that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has made of the merits and the prospects of the peace process. This was evidenced by the testimony of the then Deputy Secretary of that Department, Mr Michael Costello, to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in February last year. I quote Mr Costello's reply to two of my questions. His first answer was:

SPEECH.PARA: Anyone who puts his hand over his heart and says, `I trust Pol Pot' is probably not being all that wise. The question you have to ask is not whether you can trust these people . . . but whether the mechanisms, the institutions, the structures, are such as to give you a reasonable prospect that they will be implemented . . .
His second answer was:

People ask, `Can you guarantee . . . there will not be an outbreak of fighting?'. The answer is, `Of course I can't'. What I can say is that I am absolutely certain that fighting will continue if nothing is done.

It is precisely such a renewed outbreak of fighting which has led to the Opposition's recent doubts about this peace process. However, we believe that it is too early to predict that the fighting will continue and escalate in a way that puts the process in serious doubt. There is every chance that UNTAC can mediate a reimposition of this cease-fire. We will have to wait and see.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats note and endorse the categorical assurance of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that Australian personnel are being deployed in Cambodia to keep the peace and not to enforce it. We also note his statement that Australian and other UN forces would have to be withdrawn if the peace process collapses. That would be a great tragedy for the Cambodian people and I am sure that we all hope it does not happen.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) and officers of his Department deserve much credit for the internationally recognised role they have played in developing the only viable solution to the Cambodian conflict. The Australian members of UNTAC can feel justly proud of their involvement in Cambodia. As Australians, we can be proud of this continuation of Australia's long and honourable record in United Nations peacekeeping. The Democrats fully endorse the Prime Minister's statement and support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Government, I welcome very much the support for this motion that is now apparent from all corners of the Senate. I also welcome the generally much more moderate, balanced and constructive tone of the Opposition's contribution to this debate compared with some of the more insensitive and, arguably, opportunistic statements of recent days. I say that certainly so far as Dr Hewson's contribution, which I heard most of, but less so, so far as Senator Hill's contribution, but I guess old habits die hard.
