PARA.TAB: Nonetheless, it is clear that there is a very strong understanding in the Australian community of the virtues of the settlement that has been reached, of the stakes that are involved in its carrying through to fruition and of the utility and, indeed, necessity of Australia's involvement. I am glad that the Opposition has now come quite explicitly to appreciate all that and to make clear its support for this involvement and for the particular motion before the Parliament today.

This is the biggest peacekeeping task that the United Nations has ever attempted. It is obvious in that context, given continuing uncertainties in a number of respects on the ground in Cambodia, that there should be a number of loose ends in the way in which the UNTAC operation has so far been described and in the way in which it will proceed. However, I do not think there are as many as have been suggested by the Opposition in this respect. But may I say quickly that the Government is perfectly happy to consult with the Opposition and to share with it the information as it becomes available. Certainly I will do what I can now in this reply to respond to some of the specific questions that have been asked.

There have been difficulties in bringing on a full scale parliamentary debate on this subject before this time simply because of the time it has taken in New York to get the operational plan prepared and at a sufficiently clear-cut stage of implementation in terms of identifying the tasks to be performed, who is being asked to do them and Australia's role in that respect. It has taken some time for all that to occur to the point at which we could make meaningful decisions and have a meaningful discussion. But there is quite a bit that we can now say. It has already been said in the statement, and I will do my best to supplement that in some respects.

As to the concerns that have been expressed, I will begin with the theme, repeated again today by Senator Hill, of the role of the Khmer Rouge in this settlement. I am as conscious as anyone in the world of the appalling record of the Khmer Rouge. I am certainly not a naive advocate of the view that it has now become converted to the democratic process intellectually, emotionally or in any other way. However, I have been of the view for quite a considerable time that no settlement would ever be possible of the appallingly protracted, disastrous situation in Cambodia unless it involved in some credible way all parties active on the ground in Cambodia, and did not seek to exclude one altogether from that process, whatever the obvious attractions in doing so.

The justification for that, as I have explained on innumerable occasions, is our belief that to crudely try to exclude the Khmer Rouge or anybody else from the process would not have made possible a commitment to that settlement process by the relevant external powers whose support, more than anything else, was keeping the conflict going. More specifically, it would not have been possible to include China in the settlement process without a role being found in the way that the settlement process now sets it out for all the parties on the ground; not a role in the actual executive administration of the country—that was impossible to accept—but a role as potential participants in the future of that country through the ballot box.

The Khmer Rouge have not, in our judgment, necessarily changed their spots at all. We can make no judgment about that and certainly I have no optimism, as I have said, on that score. What we can make a judgment about is that they have been effectively denied a continuation of external arms support and they very clearly have been denied any kind of external political support. As was said by Mr Costello in the passage quoted by Senator Bourne, what the settlement has been all about is creating the structures, the institutions, and the processes to give us the best possible chance that that settlement would be enabled to be put into place, even with the at best very grudging cooperation of one of the key internal players.

If we have been wrong in our assessment that the Khmer Rouge was capable of being contained in this way and that the settlement was only capable of being achieved by the kinds of approach I have described, then we have not been alone in that misjudgment. It has been an error also perpetrated, adopted and endorsed by all members of the Permanent Five of the Security Council, the Security Council itself, the UN General Assembly as a whole, and certainly all the key neighbouring Asian nations, from Vietnam and Thailand to the other ASEANs to Japan. Every one of those countries has come to accept over the course of the last few years that this kind of settlement strategy, the one on which we are now embarked, was the only game in town.

No-one doubts, even in the context of that settlement and with all the institutional processes that are being put into place, that the Khmer Rouge will lack the capacity for mischief in the future. They will retain that capacity and, depending on the degree of success of the demobilisation exercise and the location and destruction of arms caches exercises, there may be some considerable residual capacity for mischief. But our judgment—again, I believe, a judgment shared by all the other countries that have participated in this process—is that that capacity for mischief is eminently containable and certainly, again, that there is no alternative but to go down the course that has been mapped out.

Much has been made in recent days as a demonstration of that kind of mischief that the Khmer Rouge can perpetrate of the situation around Kompong Thom, where fighting has taken place of a kind which has given rise to quite a degree of concern. However, let me say this about that situation in Kompong Thom which has attracted so much media attention and political discussion. At most, the fighting involved was sporadic and low level in character. Much more importantly, despite the concern that has been expressed about its continuation, all the available evidence is that that situation has now been brought back under control; that the military situation there has stabilised. Lieutenant-General Sanderson made it reasonably clear that that was his expectation in an interview he did 24 or 48 hours ago that was widely reported here in Australia.

I am now able to advise the Senate on the basis of the latest information to hand this morning that it has been reported at the level of Mr Akashi, the Secretary-General's representative, and Lieutenant-General Sanderson, who have just given a briefing to the P5 countries and others, including ourselves, in Phnom Penh, that they have been encouraging developments that should assuage the concern of the past few days.

In particular, 2DK—in other words, the Khmer Rouge liaison officers—have been taken by UN helicopter to Kompong Thom. A meeting of factional liaison officers and members of the mixed military working group has been held. On yesterday morning, 31 March, CPAF—that is, the SOC Army, Cambodian People's Armed Forces—headquarters in Phnom Penh informed UNTAC that the NADK—that is, the Khmer Rouge forces—on routes 12 and 6 had withdrawn from their positions on those roads which they had previously cut off, and that a de-mining exercise by the CPAF had begun.

Some matters of detail remain to be sorted out still, but it was proposed and expected that the two companies and support elements from the Indonesian battalion now in the Phnom Penh area will be deployed to Kompong Thom to start detailed reconnaissance of the area. So that particular situation does now seem, as I have said, to be stabilised and back under control.

I guess we can go on expecting situations of this kind to occur from time to time. It is not so much a matter of the Khmer Rouge or others of the factions attempting to win territory for territorial purposes in the skirmishing and manoeuvring that is going on. What is really behind this kind of fighting, as we assess it at the moment, is essentially tactical manoeuvres intended more than anything else as political statements to the Cambodian people rather than as demonstrations of intent to resile from, to walk away from, the process.

As such, if that is a correct assessment or interpretation of what is going on, I guess we can unhappily expect a few more such political statements to occur, but maybe rather less as more and more UNTAC troops arrive on the scene able to be deployed and as the confidence building that is associated with their presence in the country takes hold—and that is certainly, I know, the hope of Lieutenant-General Sanderson and the military authorities.

So far as the concern that has been expressed about insufficient detail in the UN plan, it is the case that in most of the public statements, including the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), we have not spelt that out in great detail. But I do remind the Senate, and I remind Senator Hill in particular, that there is an enormous amount of detail spelt out in the report of the Secretary-General on Cambodia, which is a public document of the Security Council dated 19 February. I will table this document at the conclusion of my speech in order that it is available for more convenient reference by honourable senators.

The document in question is a 43-page one which does explain in a great deal of detail the present operational plan and, indeed, all the seven different components of the UN operation that are being put in place. Those components in summary are as follows in the order in which they appear in this document. First, there is the human rights component, which involves both education and oversight and the establishment of a human rights office as part of the civilian administration in Phnom Penh. Secondly, there is the electoral component, which will involve this hugely complex function of registration of voters and the conduct of the election itself, once the demobilisation is complete and the repatriation and return of refugees is complete.

The third—and of course most immediately relevant—is the military component, which has itself four main sub-components in terms of the particular roles that are to be played. The first is verification of the withdrawal of foreign forces. The second is supervision of the cease-fire and related measures, which in turn involves a number of separate operations—regroupment, cantonment of some 200,000 military personnel, disarming of some 450,000 personnel, including the militias as well as the military, and demobilisation of at least 70 per cent—to quote the settlement—of the military, but, of course, hopefully a full 100 per cent. Let me make clear, because Senator Hill made this point, that we certainly hope, and I know the military authorities on the ground in Phnom Penh certainly hope, that a greater degree of demobilisation than 70 per cent will in practice be able to be achieved, even if it was not able to be negotiated in the settlement text.

The third main function of the military component will be weapons control, which involves monitoring the cessation of external military support in terms of weapon supply, the location and confiscation of arms caches and the storing of arms. The fourth function is assisting with mine clearance. That was the military component.

The next component is civil administration, which, as the Prime Minister's statement says, picking up the language of the text of the Secretary-General's report, is designed essentially to do everything necessary to `ensure a neutral political environment conducive to free and fair general elections'. The precise content of that civilian administration role and how it will work out in practice in terms of looking over the shoulder of the different elements of the civilian administration in Phnom Penh is still in the process of being worked out. It is impossible to be precise about it at this stage, but the task itself has been defined in reasonably clear terms, at least so far as the general principles of it are concerned.
Fifthly, there is the police component, which will involve some 3,600 police monitors on the Secretary-General's plan, to which Australia will be making a small contribution, as was announced today.

Sixthly, there is the repatriation component, which involves, of course, primarily the UNHCR and the Red Cross working with NGOs to secure the repatriation of some 350,000 people living on the Thai-Cambodian border.

Finally, there is the rehabilitation component which will require a massive aid effort by the international community, the first manifestation of which will be an inaugural meeting of the International Conference on the Reconstruction of Cambodia, or ICORC, which is planned for Japan in June and in which context Australia's bilateral aid contribution announced today will have a part to play.

The particular role to be played by the Australian forces was the subject of query by Senator Hill. Of course, it is outlined in general terms in the statement. There is not an enormous amount more I can add to what is in the statement except to say that on page 22 of the Secretary-General's report the role of the Signals Unit is described in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: A total of 582 (all ranks) would be deployed throughout the mission area. This unit would be responsible for the establishment of the force communication net, including ground-to-air communications. In addition, in coordination with civilian communications staff, the unit would assist with the provision of communication to the civilian components of UNTAC.

That is the context in which I was referring last night to the Australians being involved in a civilian role as well. I was also making the obvious point that in the absence of any telecommunications infrastructure it is essentially going to be a matter for the armed forces signallers to create an equivalent, at least in very outline shape, of a Telecom system for the country. It is a huge job, and it is in that context that the numbers we are talking about should be seen.

PARA.TAB: It is not a matter of talking about 582 communicators in the context of just another 2,000, 3,000 or 4,000 people deployed. Remember that we are talking about a military component under this operational plan of 15,900 in total involving many different operational roles, including an infantry element of some 10,200 with 12 battalions of roughly 850 people each. So it is in the context of an operation of this huge scale that this particular logistic support role has been identified and will be carried out by Australia.

The deployment of the Australian troops will be a matter for the military commander on the ground, who happens, of course, to be an Australian—Lieutenant-General Sanderson—but wearing a United Nations hat, not an Australian one. It is not a matter of defining with the kind of precision that we needed to in the Gulf conflict, rules of engagement and the circumstances for the exercise of independent discretion and so on, because in the Gulf conflict the Australian component of the forces was acting as an independent agency, in effect, although in coordination, of course, with the other forces there concerned. Here it is a rather different operation where the Australians are fully integrated into a UN military exercise and are subject to UN command. Of course, it is always capable for the Australian Government to make the decision that it is unhappy about the way something is developing on the ground and to decide to withdraw the forces thus engaged. But essentially their deployment will be a matter for the UNTAC force commander.

The context in which that deployment will occur has been unequivocally made clear by Lieutenant-General Sanderson as a peacekeeping role, not a peace enforcement role. I do not honestly think there is room for any further confusion about these particular kinds of identified roles. Peace enforcement does involve something analogous to the Gulf war situation where you are going into a manifestly hostile situation, separating forces at war, exercising military force. Peace keeping, as that concept is now well understood, involves not any of that but simply the monitoring, supervision and verification of agreements already reached.

There is some ambiguity about the further expression `peacemaking'. Peacemaking is usually used in the context of preventive diplomacy or the kind of diplomacy that was involved in actually crafting and bedding down the settlements agreements signed in Paris. But there is a looser sense in which we can talk about peacemaking as being an ongoing task and we can talk about the various UNTAC components having, in a sense, an ongoing peacemaking role to the extent that their presence on the ground will involve confidence building, will hopefully involve the resolution of local disagreements and difficulties, the renegotiation of cease-fire terms, things of this kind that we have seen already happening in Kompong Thom. In an extended sense, that does involve, I suppose, a degree of peacemaking. But the basic peacemaking has been done with the settlement agreements. What is necessary simply is to ensure that those agreements work themselves out.

If the situation should deteriorate to the point where a major conflict erupts between the various Cambodian armed forces, then it will not be the job of the UN forces to endeavour to separate them, and it will become a matter for judgment by the international community as to how the situation is handled thereon in. But in the worst case scenario, it would involve, of course, the UN and the international community walking away completely from the situation on the ground. That would be a desperately unhappy outcome, but that is the logic of this kind of role, and it has been identified.

Finally, so far as the commitment of other countries is concerned—which was the subject of a further expression of concern by Senator Hill, and also by Doctor Hewson in the other place—let me say just this. We are in the early stages right now of seeing the acceptance of the invitation to supply components of UNTAC and the deployment of those components. There are Indonesian and, I understand, Malaysian battalions on the ground, as well as the existing UNAMIC contingent.

As I said last night in the Estimates Committee, on the information that came to us last night and which has been confirmed this morning from New York, a further three infantry battalions will be employed very quickly from three other countries within the next three weeks, along with a field ambulance unit, a number of police officers and military observers, an engineering unit, other logistics units, helicopters and some naval personnel, with an expected total—taking into account those already there—of 4,000 troops on the ground by the third week of April. That is only the preliminary rapid deployment. More deployment will continue to occur over the period ahead.

Everyone acknowledges that it is tremendously important to get as many people as possible on the ground before the dry season is overtaken by the wet. Certainly, it is everyone's hope and expectation that there will be many more troops than just 4,000 on the ground before the wet. However, it was important to get some people on the ground very quickly. By my calculations, approximately 20 countries are now involved, taking those functions I have just described into account, and no doubt there will be many more before the process is complete. That is just the military operation and unquestionably other countries will be involved in the electoral function and other aspects of civilian organisations, as well as the policing function which will be very important.

A question was also raised about the commitment of other countries towards paying the costs of this operation which are very large. The sum of $1.9 billion is the estimate for the 18-month period and Australia's contribution as a proportion of that has been spelt out. It is the case that to my knowledge a substantial number of contributions have not yet actually been made even to the initial $200m advance amount that has been formally agreed. One would not expect contributions to be paid as yet for the larger UNTAC assessed costs, simply because that has not yet been the subject of a final formal decision. When it is, there is an obligation on countries to pay their assessed contribution within 30 days of that and we can expect to see a rapid influx of money.

One piece of good news that I am able to report as a result of a cable received a few hours ago from Washington, is that yesterday the US House of Representatives voted very strongly in favour of a $270m appropriation for peacekeeping dues, the largest proportion of which will be set aside for the US share of UNTAC expenses.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank God for that.

—That is only the House of Representatives; we still have the Senate to go. That is expected in the next 24 hours. If it gets mixed up with the housing settlement money in Israel, God knows what will happen, but the hope is that the money will come through steadily. The pieces are falling into place. I can understand some anxiety being expressed about various bits and pieces of the total operation. However, I do ask parliamentarians and the Australian public to be a little patient because of the extraordinary complexity of the task.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I will quote from the Secretary-General's report about this matter. The following words appear on the opening page by way of introduction to all the information which then follows:

SPEECH.PARA: It should be noted however that, in spite of the efforts made by these missions, the information obtained cannot be regarded as complete and current assessments regarding priorities and deployment may prove to be inaccurate, as circumstances in Cambodia change. The specific recommendations contained in the present report may therefore need to be re-examined in the light of experience, once UNTAC is in place.

The urge for absolute certainty in terms of who will be deployed where, from which countries and at what cost is just a misplaced urge at this stage. It is a step by step exercise. We have done very well indeed to get the first steps in place, but there are many more to go.

PARA.TAB: The Government has not sought to underestimate the risks associated with this exercise. Australian troops—as will everyone else on the ground in Cambodia in either civilian or military roles—will face risks from disease, mines and also from the possibility of cross-fire in the event that the military situation does deteriorate. In that environment it is crucial for everyone to acknowledge the legitimacy or the validity of the task upon which we are all embarked. It is absolutely crucial that everyone in Cambodia who is working for peace—including the very talented, skilled and devoted members of the Australian defence forces—feel that they have the support of the Australian community and Parliament. Today that support has been essentially forthcoming from members of the Opposition, the Democrats and, I expect, from Senator Harradine and I thank them all for that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is most unfortunate that when Senator Evans accepted the support of the Opposition and the Democrats for the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on the Cambodian peacekeeping mission, he made some very churlish remarks at the beginning about the Opposition and, in particular, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill. Senator Evans attempted to repair that somewhat at the end of his speech, but it was a pity that he set the tone of his response which was not at all justified by the support which the Opposition is giving to the extended motion moved by Senator Robert Ray. The Opposition clearly supports the affirmations of support in the Parliament for Australia's participation in the Cambodian peacekeeping operation, and the participation of the Australian Defence Force, in particular, which has a most important role.

PARA.TAB: Throughout this debate on Australia's role in, and contribution to, peacekeeping in Cambodia, Senator Evans has always expected the Opposition to give him a blank cheque and a pat on the back. I hope that now he has received a pat on the back from the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) in another place, and from Senator Hill in the Senate, he will feel a little better. Nevertheless, we have not been prepared to give him a blank cheque, nor will we give him a blank cheque today.

The fact is that this proposed operation, which has been the subject of a great deal of discussion in the United Nations and throughout the world, is recognised in the statement itself as the most ambitious, comprehensive, costly and, without doubt, the most dangerous peacekeeping operation which the United Nations has ever undertaken. It is undertaking this operation in one of the most notoriously difficult, dangerous and unstable places in the world and which has been so for at least two or more decades. It was not surprising that the Opposition—indeed anyone—would wish to be satisfied that the position had been reached where a proper peacekeeping operation, albeit one of great complexity and danger, could be undertaken.

This is not, by any means, a pedantic concern of the Opposition's. The Prime Minister in his statement, Senator Evans in answer to questions the day before yesterday and Senator Ray in answer to a question yesterday have all emphasised the nature of a peacekeeping operation as distinct from a peace enforcing or imposing operation. That has gone to the heart of the Opposition's concerns, which have been expressed, largely by Senator Hill, over the time in which this operation has been debated.

The Prime Minister's statement, which was tabled here this afternoon by Senator Ray, states that the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia, UNTAC, will have a peacekeeping role which is described as supervising, monitoring and verifying the cease-fire, partial demobilisation of armed forces—we should bear in mind the nature of those armed forces in Cambodia—and the cessation of external military assistance. That is the military role of UNTAC. I want to address myself to that in the remarks that I am making in this debate.

Senator Evans has indicated that UNTAC has many other roles. They are important roles, but I think we are really focusing on the military role today. We are supporting the Government's decision to send an Australian contingent of 495 members of the Australian Defence Force to form what is called a force communications unit. Its role has now, thankfully, been spelt out in more detail by Senator Evans in the speech that he has just made. That role, as described, cannot be carried out by the Australian forces. It cannot be carried out by any of the United Nations military forces in Cambodia unless there are circumstances present in that country which enable that role to be performed. This is precisely because of the concerns about the nature of the conditions in Cambodia in recent months, or indeed in recent years, and what could be done in a peacekeeping role in the circumstances as they have been and as they may be up to the present.
If anyone still has any doubts about the justification for concern in these matters, one has to look only at the first page of the Prime Minister's statement. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: If conditions are right in Cambodia, the Government expects that the main Australian contingent will begin deploying during this month.

Today the Government is still saying `if the conditions are right in Cambodia'. That is what the Opposition has wanted to be satisfied about for months and months. Senator Evans has talked incessantly here and all around the world about the settlement in Cambodia, in which he has played a prominent and leading role. That has been acknowledged. I hope he feels better that Dr Hewson acknowledged it in his speech in another place this afternoon. If that is all he has been worried about, he has been given that acknowledgment. That is not the question. The question is whether or not it is possible to mount a peacekeeping operation of this complexity and size in the circumstances as they are in Cambodia.

PARA.TAB: The latest information coming forward from Cambodia is from the United Nations commander, Lieutenant-General Sanderson, who is a distinguished Australian soldier. I take the opportunity of congratulating him personally on his appointment and his promotion to Lieutenant-General. We have every confidence in him. We need to be assured, as does the Government, that the conditions are right in Cambodia. It is clear that the Government cannot say even today in the statement for which we waited about five months that the conditions are right and that the main Australian contingent, another 430 signallers, or communicators as they now seem to be known as, will be on their way to Cambodia. It has not been said today that they are going. It has only been said that if the conditions are right, they will be going before the end of this month. We hope that the conditions will be right and that they will be able to get started on this most important task. We have the greatest respect for them and we are confident that they will perform this task with their usual professional competence.

There is no doubt and no worries whatsoever about the ability of members of our Defence Force to play the role that is expected of them. It is a question of the conditions there and whether they are suitable for them to play this role. All along we have been supportive of the peace process. It is certainly now looking promising that that process will be able to be brought into effect. Nevertheless, one must have grave concerns about the enormity of the task in the time frame that has been laid down here. It is an enormous task to demobilise these forces, establish UNTAC as virtually a government in Cambodia, establish the conditions and administration for an election, repatriate hundreds of thousands of Cambodians back to Cambodia from the border camps and so on, yet it is intended that all that will be achieved in time for an election to be held in May 1993. Those are the sorts of concerns that we have had.

I have already indicated what the military role is. Senator Evans also spelt it out better in his speech today. He provided some answers to questions I would have been wanting to ask had he not done so. They are not really clearly spelt out in this statement. Let us look at the task that this United Nations peacekeeping force will have to perform during this period of 12 months or perhaps less. The force will have to disarm something like 450,000 Cambodian soldiers representing the various factions. They have to be brought into what is called a cantonment where they can be disarmed. As much of that as possible will have to be done during the wet season, which will create great difficulties, as will the fact that the country is infested with mines. The other role, as Senator Evans said today, is to seek out, seize and take away from the factions caches of arms, which are no doubt very extensive throughout the country. It is an enormous role. It is one which will test to the extreme the forces that will be available.

Senator Evans admitted today that only about 4,000 members of the UNTAC military mission would be in place by the end of April; and maybe it will not be achieved as soon as that. The estimate of what is required is about 15,900 military personnel, together with 3,500 civilian police and another 3,000 or more civilian administrators. The number that is to be in place by the end of this month, as Senator Evans has told us today, is far short of 16,000—in fact, it is only a quarter of the size of the military component of UNTAC.

Senator Evans has indicated that if the conditions are right and the Australians get into Cambodia by the end of this month, as everybody is hoping will be possible, they will be establishing the communications for a total of 16,000, or perhaps 10,000 or so troops in the field—in Cambodia. They will also have the wider role of providing communications for vital civilian administration. That will be most important from the point of view of establishing conditions whereby elections can be held in Cambodia and a stable administration can be put in place. The members of the Australian Defence Force will have a very important role. They will not all be serving with the military personnel that have been provided. Senator Evans has said that there will be up to 20 other countries—although there are still a lot of ifs and buts about where those numbers will come from and whether they will all be there in due time.

Nevertheless, assuming that this all goes to plan, the members of the ADF in Cambodia will be exposed to a great many dangers. One matter of concern is that they may not be fully protected in some of the circumstances in which they will be serving. I do not think there is any doubt about that and it must be recognised. It is a matter which the Government should be addressing a little more seriously than it seems to be doing. The Government says that although it has not assessed any casualty rate, according to the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) in answer to a question yesterday—which is a rather astonishing admission by the Minister—it is recognising a variety of dangerous situations in which the ADF will be operating. It is certainly up to the Government to ensure that the maximum protection in the circumstances will be given to those members of the Australian forces. Senator Evans has spelt that out in much more detail than was given in the Prime Minister's statement in relation to that particular concern of the Opposition. But for the reasons I have just mentioned, the Opposition still has continuing concerns about the safety of ADF members and about the hazardous nature of the role that they are asked to perform.

As far as the military situation is concerned in Cambodia, the statement that we have before us recognises the doubts and difficulties that remain. It spells those out in relation to the recent fighting in Kompong Thom province. The statement says—this is a key statement in the Prime Minister's statement:
Implementation of the peace plan may well prove more difficult than its negotiation.
There are bound to be further setbacks.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, on the track record of the Khmer Rouge, there are likely to be more setbacks—without any doubt whatsoever. We are not talking about ordinary guerilla fighters; we are talking about a well-organised and well-equipped military organisation which has created mayhem throughout Cambodia for two decades or more and which is still showing signs of its past as recently as the last few days. The Khmer Rouge is a dangerous force. It is no good our hiding from that fact.

PARA.TAB: The situation is such that it may arise that a peace keeping role is not possible. That is where the real sharp point of concern must be. Who is going to decide that and what will be the actual critical circumstances in which it is decided? It is a relief to hear the Government commit itself very firmly in this statement that, if in fact it is no longer possible to keep peace in Cambodia, the Australian and other United Nations forces will have to be withdrawn.

Another matter of concern we have had and, indeed, still have, despite what Senator Evans has said, is: what control will the Australian Government have over the making of that decision, if it comes to that? Realistically, we must face the fact that that may well be the case, despite all the hopes that we have and despite the optimism that Senator Evans has, perhaps more than most other people. We may well face that.

As I understand from Senator Evans, that decision will be made by UNTAC. I suppose the most influential in that respect will be the military commander there, Lieutenant-General Sanderson. We are very fortunate, indeed, that we have a distinguished Australian soldier there commanding the force. It will give all of us and the soldiers more confidence that careful consideration will be given to their situation. Nevertheless, it is a responsibility which must be assumed and retained at all times by the Government.

Even though there will not be any rules of engagement in the ordinary sense and the command structure maintained over the Australian contingent in Cambodia, as occurred in the Gulf War and similar operations, the Australian Government has the responsibility—it will always have the responsibility, and it should recognise that—to ensure that the Australian contingent in Cambodia is not being used beyond the role which everyone so clearly acknowledges is a peacekeeping role, and a peacekeeping role only. That is not a satisfactory situation, as Senator Evans outlined it, unless the Government continues to watch that very closely. There will be very difficult decisions to make as to whether or not the borderline has been stepped over as circumstances occur from time to time in Cambodia.

TAB.TAB: Despite the statement made by the Prime Minister today, and despite fuller explanations which have addressed a number of our concerns, this remains a situation of continuing doubt and difficulty, and a very fluid and fast-changing scene. As Dr Hewson and Senator Hill have pointed out, we expect the Government to take the Opposition into its full confidence at all times, particularly when these problems may arise. We expect that this Parliament will be consulted if there is any suggestion that the Australian role or the UNTAC role is changing in Cambodia, whether that be by force of circumstance or policy decision.

PARA.TAB: This is not a one-off debate today. This is not a one-off decision we are making. The Government, the Opposition—indeed, the Parliament—will be required to maintain constant vigilance with respect to the situation. The concerns that are being debated today about the military situation in Cambodia and the role that the peacekeeping forces can successfully play there are ongoing. We will all have to share and bear the worry and the responsibility.

I am pleased to see that the Government has gone a long way in this statement towards addressing those concerns. I cannot say that the Government has alleviated those concerns but it has made it clear that it understands them and shares them. That is a big step forward as far as political debate in this country is concerned. It is for those reasons that the Opposition is supporting the Government and supporting its motion. The Opposition is not proposing any amendments.

The Opposition wants to give the fullest support, understanding and encouragement to the members of the Australian defence forces who are shouldering the very heavy burden of this very important duty—a duty not only to Australia or Cambodia but to the cause of peace in our region.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a privilege to rise to support the comprehensive statement delivered by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in the House of Representatives and by Senator Ray in this chamber this afternoon. It represents the culmination of a number of years of Australian initiative and skill in diplomacy. It reflects an emerging Australian capacity to play a role in our region and in international relations in a broader sense.

PARA.TAB: It is refreshing to see a degree of bipartisanship returning to this debate. As I have said on a number of previous occasions in this place, effective foreign policy, effective defence policy and effective trade policy can really evolve only from a bipartisan basis. Having said that, could I also say that during the time of the public debate on our Cambodian involvement, the Cambodian initiative and the Cambodian peace process, Australian opinion overwhelmingly supported the endeavours of the Government. There is no doubt in my mind that the Australian people at large, and from the very beginning of the peace process, have endorsed the involvement of Australian officials and endorsed the initiatives taken by Senator Evans. In particular, the Australian electorate has endorsed the role to be taken by our armed forces in Cambodia in pursuit of peace.

There is also no doubt in my mind that the Australian people at large acknowledge the extraordinary ability of the ADF in a peacekeeping role. That has been demonstrated time and time again over the decades of our UN involvement.

In looking at the Cambodian circumstance, it is important to begin by recognising that this was the worst civil war in Asia since the Chinese civil war of the 1940s. For a period of nearly two decades it was a particularly brutal, indeed gruesome, conflict. All civil wars are bloody; all civil wars are terribly divisive. The Cambodian civil war was absolutely murderous in its intensity and it proved to be catastrophic in its consequences, not only for that unhappy country but for the region at large. It involved border conflict with Thailand and later an outright war between the Khmer Rouge and the Republic of Vietnam.

Here this evening in the context of the Prime Minister's statement we are endeavouring to deal with the consequences of that civil war, and doing so as a government, as a parliament, in a deliberate and effective way. The Government never sought a blank cheque in this regard, from either the Opposition or the Australian people. We did expect that all Australians would rise to the challenge before the country and the ADF and it is now apparent that the challenge has been met.

Every peacekeeping initiative in which the Australian armed forces have been involved has been extremely dangerous. There is no doubt about that. During the course of the review of our peacekeeping operations by the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade we were personally and directly told by officers of the ADF who had served in peacekeeping missions just how dangerous the task had proved to be. That was especially true of the role of the ADF in the Iran-Iraq peacekeeping mission. In that situation some of our officers separated large contingents of Iraqi and Iranian military personnel who were armed with heavy weapons and separated by only a few metres of mine-strewn territory. At times some of our personnel showed quite astonishing courage in performing the task of keeping those forces separate and avoiding further eruption in a war that had lasted the best part of a decade.

All peacekeeping initiatives are dangerous. The Cambodian venture is dangerous. There is no doubt about that. However, to put it in perspective, compare and contrast it with the Yugoslav involvement where a United Nations protective force is about to be deployed in that strife-torn country. As Senator Jones asked the other day in a question to Senator Evans, there is every chance that the civil war in Yugoslavia will erupt again. That is an unfortunate truth that confronts us. Nonetheless, the United Nations has a role to play in that country, just as it has a role to play now in Cambodia.

Mr Ian Harris, the Executive Director of CARE, said in a recent statement that this venture represents our last chance for peace in Cambodia; that if this initiative breaks down, we are going to see a return to circumstances that plagued Cambodia for the best part of a decade.

It is particularly satisfying to note that an outstanding Australian officer in Lieutenant-General Sanderson has command of the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia. That is particularly satisfying. It is well earned and it is a mark of international respect, not only personally for Lieutenant-General Sanderson but also for our armed forces in the broad, given the role that we have played in a range of peacekeeping missions right across the globe.

It is also satisfying to note the cooperative nature of the venture, with troops being committed from a number of countries, including New Zealand, already. It is very satisfying to note the fact that Mr Michael Maley of the Australian Electoral Commission will act as the deputy electoral commissioner for UNTAC. I pay tribute to Mr Maley for his performance in Namibia and for the performance generally of the Australian Electoral Commission over recent years in building and rebuilding, in different and very difficult political circumstances, the electoral framework in a range of countries.

There is no doubt that one of the key elements in the successful conclusion of the negotiations which have led to the formation of UNTAC is the fact that external assistance to the armed forces, to the factions, in Cambodia has come to an end. The cessation of Chinese military assistance to the Khmer Rouge is a central fact on which the peace process pivots.

There is no doubt that the Khmer Rouge has an absolutely bloody and intolerable history. There is no doubt that it can continue to create mischief for some time to come, as apparently it is doing in the Kompong Thom province at the moment. But there is no doubt also that that capacity over time will come to a halt. The successful conclusion of a peacekeeping mission and of general elections in Cambodia will hasten that end.

In the House of Representatives this afternoon, Dr Hewson earned more than a few points with the very reasonable approach that he took to the Prime Minister's statement and with his remarks, bordering on the generous, about Senator Evans. There is no doubt, though, that Senator Evans's performance on Cambodia has been outstanding. There is no doubt also that the Australian Parliament should be proud of the role taken by the Foreign Minister and his officers, just as we are proud of the role that is being carried out and will be carried out by our armed forces personnel in Cambodia.

None of us should be under any illusions about the magnitude of the task that confronts the United Nations in Cambodia. The UN has embarked upon nothing less than the rebuilding of a Cambodian political infrastructure. The UN has embarked upon nothing less than building a new government of Cambodia for the Cambodian people for the future, based upon their own decisions through the ballot box. The United Nations has also embarked upon a process which could lead to Cambodia being readmitted as a full member with all rights in the international community of nations.

It is also pleasing to note from the Prime Minister's statement that the multi-disciplinary approach that is being taken by the United Nations is reflected in the determination of the Australian Government to make substantial sums of aid available to Cambodia, as the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, Mr Kerin, has made clear through the allocation of some $49m in Australian development assistance.

There is no doubt that if a new world order is emerging, Cambodia is a very great test of that order. When I use the expression `new world order', I am talking about a system of international relations which is based upon the principles embodied in a charter of the United Nations. Cambodia is a very early and very great test of that new system of conflict resolution and rebuilding.

It is instructive to compare and contrast the Cambodian situation with that which exists in Yugoslavia. There is no doubt in my mind that in both circumstances there are likely to be setbacks, there are likely to be challenges to the authority of the United Nations and there are likely to be dilemmas that confront us. There is no doubt in my mind that, in both circumstances, the agencies of the United Nations will prove equal to the task. I speak as a member of a political party that, as Senator Bolkus knows only too well, has fought for the authority of the United Nations to prevail since its inception in San Francisco in 1945 at the end of the Second World War. The UN demonstrated its worth recently in the Gulf conflict. I believe that it will demonstrate its worth in bringing to an end the Yugoslav civil war and in bringing to a successful conclusion the peacekeeping mission in Cambodia.

The circumstances which led to the prime ministerial statement delivered in the House of Representatives today are those of careful deliberation. There has been an ongoing public debate about our involvement in Cambodia but as I have mentioned previously, there is no doubt where Australian public opinion resides on this matter. Australians have confidence in our capacity to build a peaceful settlement, to find a peaceful solution. And Australians have confidence in the capabilities of our military in the peacekeeping role. That has led to our commitment to Cambodia.

There is no doubt either that the successful evolution of an enduring peace depends very largely on the Cambodian people themselves—not upon the factions, not upon the different military groupings, but upon the Cambodian people. They have suffered greatly. They have suffered terrible injury. But there appears to be no reason to doubt their desire and their determination to make deliberate decisions in the very near future through the instrument of the ballot box. When that happens, I believe we are well on the way to achieving an enduring and just peace for Cambodia and for its people.

In particular, I endorse the Prime Minister's remarks about the pride with which Australian Defence Force units can be viewed for having played instrumental roles in peacekeeping operations in the Sinai, in Iran and Iraq, in the Western Sahara and, most recently of course, in Namibia. That same remark can also be made about officers of the AFP in Cyprus.

In my view, what we all want to see this evening as we debate the Prime Minister's statement is an identical conclusion. We are looking to the future of Cambodia and the region. That really is the vital concern. We are aiming to achieve enduring peace, enduring stability in Cambodia and the region, enduring democracy and enduring progress for Cambodia and for its people. I am very proud to be part of a government that took the initiatives that led to the Prime Minister's statement being delivered in the Parliament today. I conclude by saying that it is refreshing to see bipartisanship return to the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I rise to support the statement on Cambodian peacekeeping and the motion that is before the Senate, I am disappointed about two aspects of the debate. First of all, I am disappointed at claims by Government members, which we have just heard again from Senator Loosley, about a past so-called lack of bipartisanship on this issue. As Senator Loosely would know full well, this is not the truth. Secondly, I am disappointed at the lack of detail in the statement on the military deployment aspects.

PARA.TAB: Let me be quite clear about this so-called lack of bipartisanship. There has not been any failure of bipartisanship on this issue. There have been genuinely held and expressed concerns about the timing and the propriety of the deployment while the offensive continues. But there has been no lack of bipartisanship. What the Government means by that allegation is that an Opposition has no right to question the wisdom of this Government. Of course, I utterly reject that claim.

I turn now to my second disappointment, that is, the lack of detail on what is essentially a military operation. I do not quibble with the Foreign Affairs imprint on the document; obviously it needs to be there. But I do resent the lack of information on the involvement and the deployment of our Force. Senator Hill and Senator Durack have detailed some of the matters we would have expected to have seen included in the statement, so I do not intend to repeat them this evening. Senator Ray's involvement in this document seems to have extended merely to tabling the document in the Senate.

As the wife of an infantryman who was seen off to war in Vietnam by a Parliament which did lack bipartisan support for the involvement, I believe that it is extremely important that it be put firmly on the record that these 495 service men and women have the strong support and confidence of the Federal Opposition. We have, however, expressed our concern not at their abilities, not at their professionalism in the face of danger, but at the lack of information on the current situation in Cambodia over the past weeks.

We have been kept in the dark by the Government while the much vaunted peace process has been wobbling. Reports from Cambodia have been very disturbing. We believe that our forces are there as peacekeepers, not as foreign participants in a civil war. We have been concerned that their introduction may be premature. Indeed, even the Government, in the statement on Cambodia, indicates that that might be the case. The statement says:

SPEECH.PARA: If conditions are right in Cambodia, the Government expects that the main Australian contingent will begin deploying during this month.

Clearly, there still is the possibility of delay and I would hope that the Government will be putting the safety of our troops first before any need to rush in to be one of the leaders of deploying UN peacekeepers to Cambodia. There is no prize for winning if we take substantial casualties. One cannot help wondering what would have been the role of the main force of our troops if they had already been deployed up-country when the current hostilities had broken out.

PARA.TAB: The statement refers to the recent fighting in Kompong Thom province. When my colleague the Leader of the National Party, Mr Tim Fischer, visited Cambodia in the New Year, he visited that area. At that time, rocket firing from five to seven kilometres away was clearly heard. He visited the various factions. He had some opportunity to visit our aid workers and projects, and he saw our contingent in Phnom Penh.

I also hope to visit our troops in Cambodia during July, just as I visited the first contingent of our peacekeepers in Namibia several years ago. They brought honour on our Defence Force, as I am sure will the Cambodian force. They will be leaving families at home who will worry and wait as we did when our men went to Vietnam in the 1960s and the early 1970s. I have already visited the wife of one of our peacekeepers in my home State of Tasmania. I say to those families that they will not be forgotten. While I hope and trust that the Defence Force and the Federal Government will spring to their aid if they need help over the next year, I also promise that any help which I, as the shadow Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, can give I will gladly give.

Turning to the military aspects of the deployment, I must emphasise a matter which has not been spelt out but which must be given attention. I refer to the rules of engagement. What will the arrangements be for changes in the military situation whereby our personnel may need to take action to defend themselves? Who will determine when the rules of engagement are to change? What will the involvement of the Australian Government be in such decisions? What likelihood of delay will there be? The reason for asking these questions is only too clear. Our experience in the Gulf war was that our naval commanders were waiting for commands back in Australia, waiting on the Department of Foreign Affairs, which had no understanding of the pressures of the situation, the time constraints, and the lives of all men on board who needed to be protected.

When the Government states today that it does not underestimate the need to take every prudent precaution to protect our troops, it must recognise that the working relationships between the United Nations, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Department of Defence, and Lieutenant-General Sanderson, could be very critical to the protection of our troops. I have every confidence in General Sanderson, an extremely capable officer with a strong moral fibre. But the UN is a very bureaucratic and slow-moving organisation and problems occurred in Namibia for our force because of that bureaucracy.

While Defence assessed the possible casualties in Namibia as likely to be between 2 and 3 per cent prior to deployment, one can only assume in the absence of such information from the Government that that assessment must be at least as great for Cambodia. The same problems exist of unmapped minefields and armed men still engaging in sporadic fire fights. The assessment in Namibia, fortunately, was over-pessimistic, and I trust that it will not be correct for Cambodia.

I direct the Government's attention to the value of sending some of our infantry to work with our specialist troops on these United Nations peacekeeping deployments. The safety of our specialist troops would be enhanced, and of value also would be the experience gained by our very professional infantry who to date have had minimal opportunity to get peacekeeping experience. I understand that the United Nations prefers to ask for infantry units from other countries and specialist units from countries such as Australia, but I do urge the Australian Government to look at this question more closely.

The Opposition supports this deployment of our troops. It also supports the motion of the Government and the statement that was put before us today. We wish our troops well, confident in their ability and proud of their professionalism. We look forward to hearing of their service and to welcoming them safely home.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion and the statement on Cambodia made by the Government. As one who has had a long interest in seeking a peaceful solution for Cambodia, it is a very proud moment to speak to this motion. I have spoken before on many occasions in this chamber and I have asked many questions about Cambodia. I have had the opportunity to visit Cambodia twice—in 1988 and again in 1990. I only hope that in the coming years, particularly during the UN peacekeeping role, many members of the Australian Parliament can also visit Cambodia to see what terrible events have occurred in that country over the last few years and so that they can lend their support and commitment to the Cambodian people in seeking a peaceful solution to the conflict.

PARA.TAB: I do not know what has been the longest war of the twentieth century, but I suspect the fighting that has been going on in Cambodia, in one form or another, since 1941 means that Cambodia has probably had the longest war of the twentieth century. It is in something like its fiftieth year of war. There was the fighting in World War II. There was the fighting against the French for Cambodian independence. Once that was achieved, there was the beginning of the insurgency by the Khmer Rouge during the late 1950s and the 1960s. Then there was the involvement of the Vietnamese and the Americans along the borders of Cambodia as a result of the Vietnam war. Then there was the direct American intervention in Cambodia.

In 1970 there was the coup which led to a terrible civil war, which extended until 1975 when the Khmer Rouge triumphed. Then there was the terrible period of the Khmer Rouge in which there was not much fighting; it was just slaughter of their own people. There was the Vietnamese intervention in 1979 to get rid of the Pol Pot Government. Throughout the 1980s there was again civil war as the various factions—the Khmer Rouge, the Sihanouk faction, and the Son Sann faction—fought against the government installed in Phnom Penh by the Vietnamese.

It is not too much of an exaggeration to say that Cambodia's has been the longest war of the twentieth century. The untold suffering through at least three generations of Cambodians has been appalling. But today we are talking about Australia's involvement as part of the UN peacekeeping force. At long last there may be more than just a small glimmer of light for the Cambodian people. The ordinary people, through this process, will have a free election next year and a government of their own free choice, and the fighting will stop.

Australia should be very proud of the role it has played in reaching that settlement. For many years to come Australia's role in Cambodia will rank as one of our finest foreign affairs policy achievements. It will stand us in good stead throughout the countries of South East Asia that we were the honest broker, we were the ones without a vested interest and we were honestly there trying to get peace to this poor, unfortunate country which had suffered 50 years of fighting, much of it imposed on it by others.

In recognition of Australia's role, we must pay tribute to other countries. It has been mentioned in the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that Senator Gareth Evans, the present Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, and the previous Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Hayden, should be given particular credit for the roles that they played in the 1980s, and I certainly endorse that.

One should remember that, in the mid-1980s when Bill Hayden first started, he was condemned both within this country and elsewhere as being unrealistic in the proposals he put forward. He was followed by Senator Gareth Evans, who produced the red book, the comprehensive plan for the UN involvement in the peace settlement, which the UN P5 overwhelmingly adopted as its own plan. That means that Senator Gareth Evans has a very honoured place not only in the history of this country but also in the history of South East Asia. He certainly deserves the nomination for the Nobel Peace Prize, but it is a nomination that I think he would welcome sharing with a number of other major players.

Ali Alatas, the Foreign Minister for Indonesia, should be given special credit for the role that he played in chairing the Jakarta meetings. Many of them ended in deadlock, but he kept going back and calling further meetings. His assistance in that process cannot be ignored. I also think the former Prime Minister of Thailand, General Chatichai Choonhavan, must be given considerable credit for leading a number of the South East Asian countries out of their sterile policy on Cambodia. When he invited Hun Sen, the Prime Minister of Cambodia, to Bangkok in 1989, that was the psychological breakthrough that was needed in relations between the ASEAN countries and Vietnam and Cambodia. The French, as co-chairmen of the peace conference in Paris, must also be given particular credit.

I would also like to give particular credit to Hun Sen, the present Prime Minister of the Phnom Penh Government. Again and again it was Hun Sen who compromised with the other three factions that were fighting him and his Government, and that led to the comprehensive settlement. I have no doubt that if Hun Sen had been like most leaders who have some sort of power, and had refused to compromise, we would not be where we are today.

It is remarkable for a man who received little formal education, who was, at one stage, recruited into the Khmer Rouge but fled when he saw the evils of their rule in the late 1970s. He first of all became Foreign Minister in the Phnom Penh Government in the early 1980s and then Prime Minister. He continued to progress and is now a man of considerable political stature. He also deserves an equivalent nomination for the Nobel Peace Prize with the other people I have mentioned. There is much credit to be given to many. It is very pleasing that Senator Gareth Evans, in particular, from Australia is one of those who have been internationally nominated.

We now have the UN going in with a peacekeeping force—that may, in the end, total 15,000 soldiers and several hundred administrators—to run the country for the holding of free elections in May next year. It will be the biggest UN involvement in any country directly, at a cost of $2 billion, of which our assessed contribution will probably be in excess of $30m.Our direct role, as the statement shows, is to provide several hundred soldiers, mainly communications soldiers because of our expertise in that area. We have also announced that we will be providing a senior electoral official to prepare for the elections next year. We will also be providing other officials as required through the UN. So Australia's role in that country will be significant as part of the UN involvement.

I would also like to take this opportunity to place on record the appreciation Australia should show to a number of other Australian citizens who have contributed over the years to getting a peace settlement in Cambodia. Others I have already mentioned. There is the now important role that Lieutenant-General Sanderson will play as the chief military officer of the UN peacekeeping force. I agree with other speakers who say there is no more commanding soldier, a soldier with intellect, who can take on that job. Australia is very well served by having such an officer available as Lieutenant-General Sanderson.

Mention has been made of Colonel Russell Stuart, already wounded in carrying out his duties in Cambodia. I first met Russell Stuart some two years ago after he had made several visits to Cambodia as part of initial inquiries about the situation in the country. Russell Stuart is a soldier of considerable initiative. He assessed the situation in the country and often made reports that disagreed with much of the propaganda put out by other countries about the true situation. He stuck to his guns and he has been proven right in his assessment of how a peacekeeping operation could work. Russell Stuart is deserving of special commendation for the work he has already put in in getting a peacekeeping force into operation in Cambodia.

I would like to mention three Australians who I do not think are well known in this country, although they are very well known in Cambodia. One of them is Jennifer Ashton. Jennifer founded the Australian non-government aid office in Phnom Penh in the mid-1980s. She served there for nearly three years, in effect, as the de facto ambassador for Australia, but running the distribution of Australia's aid into that country. Jennifer did a sterling job under considerable difficulties. I first met her there in 1988. It should be noted that she was recently appointed by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to oversee the return of 300,000 refugees from the Thai border into Cambodia. That is a mark of the assessment others have made about her capability. We all wish Jennifer very well both for the work she has done and for the work she will be doing in the future.

Lyndal McLean, who was Jennifer's successor in the NGO office in Phnom Penh, took leave from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. She is now back in Phnom Penh as the political counsellor in our reopened embassy. Lyndal was an outstanding officer both within the Department and in her job with the NGO office. She did much to educate many of us about the need for a peace settlement for Cambodia. Like Jennifer, she is dedicated and passionate. Lyndal deserves full credit from all Australians for the work that she has already done and the work she will continue to do.

Another person who represents Catholic Relief in Phnom Penh is Onesta Carpeni. She is a Belgian by birth but has represented Australian NGO interests in Phnom Penh throughout the 1980s. She has played a major role in representing the interest not only of Australian Catholic Relief but also of Australia. She has been a passionate supporter of getting a peace settlement for Cambodia.

I believe that those three women in particular are the sorts of people who do Australia proud anywhere in the world. Hopefully, one day they will get recognition in Australia through the appropriate awards.

This statement today indicates that Australia has had a major foreign policy success in its initiatives in Cambodia. There is still a long way to go. There will still be many twists and turns and many disappointments. Unfortunately, I suspect that there will still be many people killed in Cambodia—if not deliberately, then accidentally—because of the mines that have been left as a result of the long war.There can be no doubt that this has been a major policy achievement of the present Government. It will stand us in good stead for many years to come.

I also take note of the concern of many speakers that the lives of some civilian Australians in our peacekeeping force are at risk because of the unpredictable nature of the present political situation. But that is a price that Australians—certainly those Australians willing to serve there—are willing to pay. It shows that they are committed and that they know the risks. Our soldiers know the risks, but they are willing to participate in a UN peacekeeping force to achieve that peace.

I hope that I do not see it and that it does not occur, but if some Australians are killed, that should not be taken as a failure of our policy in Cambodia. There is always a risk in any situation like this. The risk should not outweigh what we are trying to achieve. I only hope that if, unfortunately, there are some casualties, there is not a mad, hysterical reaction with people saying, `Pull out of Cambodia immediately; it has been a failure'. A failure will occur only if the UN is not able to keep a comprehensive peace until the holding of a free election and the establishment of a freely elected government. We have a chance of really achieving that through this process that has been intricately put together. Let us hope that it all works.

Finally, a peace settlement in Cambodia will lead to a future for South East Asia that will be the most prosperous in its history. It will mean that Vietnam and Cambodia will probably be able to join the ASEAN nations and take part in the economic development of the region. I look forward to seeing those countries improve the standard of living of their people so that all countries in South East Asia, not just the existing ASEAN countries, can improve their standard of living.

Of course, Australia's role in South East Asia will be very important. We will, therefore, get some benefit from the peace in Cambodia and South East Asia by being able to participate in the economic development of the region as a part of the region ourselves. That is the exciting part in the long term for Australia. With peace in Cambodia and peace in South East Asia, Australia's own prosperity will be enhanced through the trading and economic development of the region.

In the long term, there are real benefits for us being involved in this risky—I admit that—and expensive UN peacekeeping force. I am sure that Australians are willing to take that risk. As we have shown over the last 100 years, when we have been called upon to take the risk to defend peace and democracy and establish a better system in the world, Australians have been willing to pay that price and take that risk. I look forward to that achievement over the next 18 months. I wish all Australians well who have committed themselves to that process, particularly those who are going to serve in Cambodia over the next two years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support all eight parts of the motion on peacekeeping in Cambodia. I acknowledge that in the Senate in this debate and in the House of Representatives there has been only support for this parliamentary motion today. The commitment to gaining a just and stable peace for Cambodia has bipartisan support in the Parliament. Those Australians who will serve as the contingent from Australia have the support and confidence of all parts of the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: There was a hint at one stage from one speaker that there was support with reservations from some members of the Opposition. I have not heard it in those terms. What I have heard is genuine, all parliamentary support for the words of this motion. What some speakers have expressed—which has been clearly acknowledged by Senator Evans, who has contributed more detail to this debate today than the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—is that there are just concerns. Certainly the Opposition has these concerns. We have expressed very precisely the concerns that we have had for some months, and that we continue to hold, alongside our support for this motion.

The end result of all the diplomatic and peacekeeping initiatives to which we refer is the self-determination of the Cambodian people, the election of their own government and the non-intervention of foreign countries in Cambodia in the civil war. I notice that the lights have gone out.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—Senator Teague, you may stand and sing or you may sit and wait a few moments. You can proceed, if you can see in the dark.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to see that honourable senators are in the chamber, the television is still broadcasting and Hansard is here to record this contribution to this important debate.

PARA.TAB: The end result of all our speaking here today is to see a successful outcome to the diplomatic and peacekeeping initiatives that have been taken by many in the world. I recognise the quite new atmosphere in the United Nations amongst the Permanent Five and the Security Council—indeed, the whole United Nations membership—in facing such a challenge as seeking to gain a just and stable peace for Cambodia. That atmosphere has changed enormously: firstly, since the end of the superpower rivalry between the United States and the Soviet Union, with the collapse of the Soviet Union's economy and the extremely improved relations between the republics that made up the Soviet Union and the United States and, indeed, all nations. Secondly, it has changed because of the very decisive action of the United Nations in the resolution of the aggression against Kuwait.

It is in this new atmosphere that we express the hope that we can bring solutions to the problems of Cambodia. Not only the children, but also the adults of that country have had a lifetime of war, civil war, death, destruction, genocide and every loss imaginable. It is to that end that we support the motion that is before us. It is to that same end that we want to guard against complacency and ensure that the Government of Australia, in acting for all Australians and our contingent forces serving in Cambodia, is accountable to this Parliament and the Australian public.

I shall refer later to the inquiry into Australia's involvement in United Nations peacekeeping operations, which is undertaken by the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I was happy to share in the formulation of that Committee's conclusions and recommendations set out in the report, United Nations Peacekeeping and Australia, which was completed and tabled in this Parliament in May last year, some 10 months ago. I want to make it entirely clear that in the undertaking of this peacekeeping mission and in all of Australia's relations to peacekeeping, all of the findings and recommendations of that report are entirely relevant.

I am happy to say that the Government has positively responded to the Senate report, but I want to ensure by highlighting some of our recommendations that it genuinely takes these recommendations into account now and ensures they form part of the guiding foundations as we move step by step into the commitment of the Australian contingent and, we hope, to a successful outcome of the whole peacekeeping activity in Cambodia.
Let me refer to a number of the recommendations of the Senate report. The first I wish to read in full is recommendation 6, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government ensure the precondition for Australia contributing to a United Nations peacekeeping force is that all parties are committed to a comprehensive settlement and to the relevant United Nations Security Council and General Assembly Resolutions and United Nations peacekeeping operational plans.
That was the unanimous finding of Government, Opposition and Democrats senators in the conduct of this inquiry into Australia's contribution to UN peacekeeping.

PARA.TAB: The pre-condition is that we can see within any country such a commitment by the parties to the comprehensive plan for resolution of what had been civil war and strife, such that it is responsible to see an international UN force of peacekeepers go in not to enforce a peace but to keep the peace that is represented by the various parties committed to that comprehensive settlement. And not only to the settlement, but also to all of the resolutions of the Security Council and the General Assembly of the United Nations. And not only to that, but also to the peacekeeping operational plans.

There is concern in the Australian public, certainly in the Opposition and I think amongst most members of this chamber, that this past week and at various times over the last several months since October when the comprehensive settlement was signed by the various parties in Cambodia, we have seen an apparent breakdown of the cease-fire, a breakdown of the bona fides of the commitment to the settlement by one or other party—in particular, by the Khmer Rouge in the northern part of Cambodia.

There was some degree of good news in Senator Evans relaying the withdrawal of the Khmer Rouge from that offensive position on Highway 12 in Cambodia. He referred in his speech to a press conference that Lieutenant-General Sanderson and Mr Akashi had given in Cambodia, I think today, indicating that there was better news—and even as I speak, the lights are coming up in the Senate—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a new dawn.

—I hear that about a new dawn. I am concerned with regard to Cambodia that there have been a number of new dawns in this respect over the last four to five months. We want to see a permanent and genuinely irrevocable commitment by the parties to the comprehensive settlement and to the operational plans that the peacekeeping force, under the command of Lieutenant-General Sanderson, will put into effect to ensure that the peace is kept in Cambodia.

PARA.TAB: The Senate Committee's recommendation 18 refers to a durable political settlement underpinning the peacekeeping operation and an acceptable time frame for the commitment. Recommendation 19 urges the Government to publicise widely in the Australian community the specific peacekeeping operation's details.

I note that in part, in response to questions for some months now from the Opposition, the Prime Minister in making the statement today addressed a number of the parameters of Australia's commitment to this peacekeeping operation which we believe are necessary for the Australian public and Parliament to know about to enable them to have confidence in the decision.

I acknowledge, as I did at the outset, Senator Evans's even more detailed statements today with regard to the wider international contribution to this peacekeeping force. He mentioned some 20 nations. He mentioned a resolution in the House of Representatives of the United States today in regard to the $270m of funding towards the $1.9 billion expected cost over the coming 18 months. He mentioned specifics of, as I say, the Khmer Rouge's apparent withdrawal from its breaking of commitments it had made to the settlement in Cambodia. These details are in the direction of recommendation 19 that the Senate Committee has underlined.
